Centers remain soft and a bit cloudy as starch loosens; outer edges start to firm and curl while narrow corners lift away from the pan. Sizzle and occasional crackle fill the air; steam rises from the pan. The cook stirs and flips pieces to distribute heat, prevent sticking, and encourage even browning along exposed sides.
finished_description: End state: golden-brown, crisp exterior with a tender, fluffy interior; evenly sized pieces hold their shape rather than mashing, with light caramelization along the edges and a glossy oil sheen. They are not mushy. The cook may be plating, finishing with salt, pepper, butter, or herbs, and serving as a side or component of a dish.

initial_description: Initial state: a single garlic clove with dry papery skin; oval, 1–2 cm long; skin pale tan to brown with purplish hints; inner flesh ivory-white, firm and smooth. The beginner might pick up the clove, hold it between fingers, place it on a cutting board, and begin applying gentle pressure with the flat of a knife to loosen the skin.
transition_description: Intermediate state shows a mix of crushed particles and mush: translucent, fibrous strands with small granules; a wet, paste-like slurry. Oil beads glisten on the surface; color stays white to ivory, sometimes faint yellow. Texture ranges from gritty mush to smooth paste as cells rupture and juices emulsify. The person applies pressure with a pestle or knife, grinding, rocking, and scraping to gather fragments into ongoing paste.
finished_description: End state: a pale yellow-white, glossy garlic paste with irregular granules. Texture is spreadable yet slightly chunky, with a light oil sheen and no large chunks. The mass forms a loose mound with small particles. They are likely transferring the paste to a pan or bowl, scraping it from the work surface, or adding it directly into a heated dish.

initial_description: Initial state: an intact biscuit, flat on a surface, round or rectangular, typically light-to-medium brown, dry and firm to the touch, with a crisp snap and clean, well-defined edges. The beginner’s action: lift the biscuit and apply gentle, steady pressure with fingers (or a blunt utensil) from its center or edge, initiating compression to begin crushing.
transition_description: In progress, the biscuit shows a mix of coarse crumbs and finer powder, with occasional damp patches. Colors range from pale beige to tan as moisture darkens spots. Texture is crumbly and dusty, with small cohesive clumps where oils bind pieces together. Particle sizes vary from gritty granules to tiny flakes; shapes are irregular. The person presses, rubs, and folds with fingers or a tool, rotating and grinding to break pieces further.
finished_description: End state: dry, crumbly biscuit crumbs—primarily uniform powder with small irregular granules; pale beige to light brown in color; texture ranges from fine to slight grit, and can be cohesive when mixed with melted butter. The person finished with crushing biscuit might immediately press the crumbs into a pan to form a crust, or blend with butter and sugar to set into a cohesive base before chilling.

initial_description: Initial state: An Oreo is intact—two round, dark brown chocolate wafers (≈4.5 cm diameter) with a pale cream filling visible between. Surfaces are smooth, slightly glossy; edges crisp and even. The cookie feels firm and dry to the touch, with a flat, uniform profile. When beginning to crush, the person picks it up, holds it between fingertips, and applies light, even pressure to test its initial give.
transition_description: Mid-crush Oreo: pieces range from chunky halves to fine crumbs, irregular edges, and a few intact cookies still connected by the center cream. Colors mix: dark brown wafers with pale beige filling visible in ruptures. Texture transitions from solid to crumbly, powdery fragments that cling in clumps; dust may coat fingers or the surface. The person applies pressure with fingers or a utensil, twisting, pressing, and smushing, monitoring fragmentation without fully pulverizing.
finished_description: End state: A bowl of Oreo crumbs, irregular pieces and powder in dark chocolate brown with pale cream specks. Particle size ranges from fine dust to small fragments a few millimeters across; texture is dry to crumbly, sometimes slightly moistened into gentle clumps. The person finished crushing may be scooping or pouring the crumbs into a crust or bowl, mixing into batter, or spreading them as a topping or base.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole cookie, intact and uncrushed. Diameter about 4 cm (roughly circular or oval), thickness about 1 cm. Color ranges from light golden brown to deep tan; surface may be glazed or matte, with visible ridges or chocolate chips. Texture: firm to the touch, depending on bake. Beginning action: the person chooses the cookie, picks it up by the edges, and places it on a surface to start applying pressure with hands or a tool.
transition_description: Mid-crush, you’ll see a spectrum of pieces: jagged shards and loose crumbs ranging from fine dust to bite-sized fragments. Colors stay warm tan to brown with visible chocolate chips or speckles. Surfaces are matte and dusty; small clumps may form where fats or moisture bind crumbs. Texture shifts from powdery to crumbly to slightly cohesive. The person is pressing, pounding, or grinding—rolling pin, mallet, or bag-and-smash—checking crumb size and uniformity.
finished_description: End state: Irregular brown crumbs and fragments in a shallow pile or bowl; sizes range from fine powder to small shards; color varies from dark to light brown; texture is dry, crumbly, and powdery with no intact cookie. The person finished might be sweeping or tapping loose crumbs, scooping them into a container, or adding them to a recipe or topping.

initial_description: Initial state: Whole potatoes, firm and unbroken, sizes from small to medium, shapes ranging from round to elongated. Skin brown/tan with dirt specks; flesh pale yellow/white. Surface may be clean or slightly rough; no crushing marks. The person starting typically handles a potato on the counter, rinses under water, and may peel with a peeler, removing eyes and trimming irregular ends before any crushing action begins.
transition_description: During crushing, potatoes sit as irregular chunks mixed with mushy areas. Pieces vary in size from slivers to larger blocks; many retain edges while others smear into a soft, cohesive mass. Color ranges from pale white to creamy tan with damp, glistening surfaces from released starch. Texture spans crumbly to tacky, with occasional smooth ribbons as heat softens starchy cells. The person uses a masher or fork, pressing and turning, occasionally scraping the bottom to mix and redistribute.
finished_description: End state: mashed/crushed potatoes that are uniformly pale, creamy, or lightly yellow. Shapes are irregular, mostly small, mash-like pieces with no large chunks; size ranges from smooth purée to pea-sized fragments. Surface appears glossy or matte depending on moisture; color ivory to light tan; skins absent (if peeled) or speckled with tiny flecks. Texture soft, cohesive, or slightly grainy with moderate moisture. After finishing, they may be scooped, plated, seasoned, or blended with butter/cream.

initial_description: Initial state: one or more standard 1x1x1 inch ice cubes resting in a tray. Cubes are uniform, translucent white to clear, with smooth faces and sharp edges, lightly frosted from cold air. Surfaces are wet and slick from condensation. A hand and a crusher or mallet are positioned nearby, the grip just beginning, preparing to apply pressure but without any deformation yet. Lighting emphasizes cool blues and whites.
transition_description: Ice shows a mosaic of irregular fragments: some larger chunks still with facets, many medium shards, and a fine granulated dust. Surfaces are frosted and damp, with translucent pale-blue to white hues and occasional glossy meltwater. Fragments cluster into wet piles and slushy pools. The crusher or hand tool is actively applying force, tapping, grinding, and turning pieces, occasionally shaking to redistribute and break remaining larger bits.
finished_description: End state: Crushed ice consists of small, irregular granules and fragments, a few millimeters in size, commonly snow-white to translucent, with a damp, fluffy, scoopable texture. Pieces are loose, not solid blocks, forming a cool, rapidly melting bed. The person finished might scoop or pour the crushed ice into a glass or blender, level the surface, or dump it into a drink, then wipe the work area.

initial_description: Initial state of crushing walnut: a single walnut in its hard, ridged shell, roughly 3–4 cm long, oval. The shell is warm brown with darker streaks; texture is dense and very hard with pronounced grooves. Inside, the kernel remains hidden. The person beginning crushing is placing the walnut into a nutcracker or gripping it with fingers, with jaws open and the nut aligned, ready to apply pressure.
transition_description: Mid-crush, walnuts present a mix of irregular shards and partially crushed chunks, ranging from fine powder to coarse fragments. Colors span tan to brown, with occasional dark shell flecks. Textures vary from crumbly, dry to slightly oily and paste-like as oils release. Surfaces show microcracks and uneven contours. The handler applies pressure with a nutcracker, grinder, or mallet, using repeated blows or grinding motions and occasional scraping.
finished_description: End state: Crushed walnuts appear as a light-to-medium brown mix of irregular fragments and fine meal. Fragment sizes range from coarse shards to powdery dust; pieces are mostly broken into small bits with some oily sheen from natural oils. Texture crumbly to slightly greasy, depending on grinding. Shape is jagged and uneven, not spherical. The user might be transferring the crushed product to a bowl or container, measuring, or mixing it into batter or dough, then cleaning up.

initial_description: Initial state: a fresh ginger root, knobby and irregular, with rough brown skin and pale yellow flesh visible at cut ends. Size varies, typically finger-length; a single piece rests on a cutting board. The person grips the fibrous knob, skin intact or just starting to peel, and applies light pressure with the flat of a knife or the palm, beginning to crush. The surface is firm, fibrous, and slightly moist, with an aromatic scent that hints at crush-ready flavor.
transition_description: Mid-crush ginger appears as a variable mash of fibrous slivers and damp pulp. Chunks range from a few millimeters to finer shreds; colors are pale tan to golden yellow with visible juice streaks. The texture is fibrous, gritty, and sticky, sometimes glistening with liquid. The worker applies pressure and shear—pounding or crushing with a mortar and pestle, or pressing against a grater—tearing fibers, scraping pulp, and bundling juices into a soft mass.
finished_description: End state: pale yellow beige paste or mash, moist and sticky, with visible fibrous strands. Particle size ranges from fine to coarse; forms an irregular, spreadable mound or sits in a small bowl. Color may darken slightly at edges from oxidation. After crushing, the person typically scoops the paste into a bowl or pan, then wipes tools and moves to cooking or adding to a recipe.

initial_description: Initial state: a single, whole strawberry. Bright red, glossy surface with visible tiny seeds, firm and plump, about 2–3 cm long with the green calyx attached. No bruising. The person starting crushing is preparing: pinching the berry by its stem between thumb and forefinger, lifting it slightly, ready to apply gentle pressure to begin crushing.
transition_description: During crushing, the strawberry mass is irregularly mashed: some pieces still chunky, others broken into small pulp. The mixture is wet, glossy, and sticky, with red juice pooling and seeds embedded in pink-red slurry. Color ranges from bright scarlet to darker pink as moisture is released. Shapes vary from flattened fragments to granular pulp and thin sheets. The person is applying pressure with a masher or spoon, mashing, pressing, and stirring to break down tissue.
finished_description: End state: a bright red-to-pink strawberry puree or mash, glossy and moist, with seeds dispersed. Texture ranges from smooth to chunky, with small fruit bits and juice; color stays vivid red. The mass sits in a bowl or on a surface, ready for jam, sauce, dessert, or baking. The person finished with crushing strawberry might be scooping, pouring, transferring the puree, stirring with sugar, or cleaning the tools.

initial_description: Initial state: an intact cracker—flat, dry, and brittle, usually square or rectangular about 2–3 inches across and 0.2 inches thick. Color pale beige to light golden brown with a crisp, porous surface and visible salt crystals or toppings. The person is just starting: they pick up the cracker and position it between the pads of the fingers (often thumb and forefinger), preparing to apply gentle pressure.
transition_description: Intermediate states show irregular cracker fragments: broken shards, flakes, and crumbs that progressively become fine powder. Sizes range from coarse chips to micro-grains; shapes are jagged and uneven. Colors remain light tan to tan-brown, with darker edges from browning. Texture shifts from dry, crisp pieces to crumbly, dusty clumps, sometimes slightly oily if exposed to moisture. The person might press, roll, crush with fingers, or grind with a rolling pin or spoon in a controlled motion.
finished_description: End state: Cracker has collapsed into loose pale beige crumbs and fine powder. Irregular fragments range from dust to a few millimeters, with a dry, crumbly, slightly powdery texture and a matte surface. No whole crackers remain; pieces are irregular and crumbly. The person may be scooping or pouring the crumbs into a bowl, sprinkling them onto food, mixing into batter or dough, or wiping up the residue.

initial_description: Initial state: whole tomatoes (varied sizes from cherry to large), round to slightly oblong, firm yet plump, with smooth, taut skins in red, orange, or yellow hues; intact stems attached or removed; no visible damage or mush. They may appear washed and dried. The person starting crushing would be selecting and arranging them on a stable surface, possibly washing, trimming stems, and placing them in a bowl or mortar to prep for crushing.
transition_description: Intermediate states reveal broken skins, irregular chunks, and a growing red slurry. Seeds disperse, juice pools, and the mass becomes sticky with glossy wet sheen. Texture ranges from coarse, lumpy bits to a more uniform, mashed pulp as pressure increases. The person might be mashing with a fork/pestle, squeezing by hand, or pressing with a masher, occasionally scraping the sides to redistribute fragments.
finished_description: End state: red tomato pulp/puree with mixed particle sizes from fine to small chunks; a moist, glossy mass that spreads into a shallow puddle or cohesive mound, sometimes with visible seeds and thin liquid separating. Color ranges from bright red to pinkish hues; texture ranges from smooth to slightly gritty; no whole pieces remain. After crushing, the person might transfer the pulp to a bowl, strain or whisk it, or begin cooking or seasoning the sauce.

initial_description: Initial state: a dry peanut, either still in its light brown, ridged shell or shelled and pale beige. In-shell peanuts are about 1.5–2.5 cm long; kernels are compact, dense, and hard. When starting, the person positions the peanut (or kernel) and applies light pressure with fingers or a tool to begin cracking the shell.
transition_description: Intermediates show heterogeneous fragments: irregular shards and slivers mixed with granular bits, gradually forming a more cohesive mass. Particle sizes range from coarse crumbs to fine granules; surfaces are often dull tan to light brown with occasional darker specks. As crushing proceeds, oils release, creating a light sheen and a damp, tacky, crumbly-to-mushy texture; moisture may smear on the container. The handler uses a pestle/mortar, grinder, or rolling pin, applying steady pressure or pulsing, scraping the sides.
finished_description: End state: ground peanut product with color ranging from tan to light brown; texture from dry, crumbly meal to cohesive paste, depending on moisture and grind; particle size from coarse crumbs to fine powder; irregular shapes with some clumps and occasional oil sheen. After finishing, the person may bag or weigh the product, add to a recipe or mix, wipe/clean equipment, or transfer to storage.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole nut in its shell, uncracked. Shell is hard, rough-textured, with ridges; shape is compact ovoid or round; size varies by species (roughly 1–3 cm). Color ranges from tan to dark brown. The nut feels dry, cool, and very firm to touch. A beginner typically grips the nut in the palm or places it in a nutcracker, stabilizing it and aligning it with the cracking surface, ready to apply pressure.
transition_description: Mid-crush, shells break into shards and powder as kernels are partially exposed and still in chunks. Crack lines and dust from fragments appear, and oil may bead on pieces. Colors shift from dark brown shell to pale beige fragmented kernels. Textures range from gritty, crumbly fragments to coarse paste, with some whole or half kernels trapped among crushed bits. The tool or hands apply steady pressure, guiding pieces toward smaller morsels.
finished_description: End state: a pile of crushed nuts consisting of irregular fragments and fine meal. Shapes are crumb-like to powdery, with sizes ranging from coarse chunks (~2–5 mm) to very fine dust (<0.5 mm). Color is light beige to tan; the surface is matte and slightly oily from nut oils, with occasional clumps when pressed. The person finished may be transferring the material to a bowl, jar, or pan, or sweeping the work area.

initial_description: Initial state: A single intact almond rests on a flat surface. If shelled, it is a smooth, elongated seed about 1.5–2 cm long, tan-brown, with a subtle seam and a hard, firm texture. If in shell, a rough, darker brown hull encloses the pale kernel. The surface is clean, dry, and solid to touch. The beginner typically grips the nut, aligns it with a nutcracker or knife, and initiates pressure.
transition_description: During crushing, almond material appears as irregular fragments from coarse slivers to fine meal. Colors shift from pale beige to light tan; surfaces become faintly glossy as oils release. The mix ranges from dry, gritty powder to a slightly sticky paste, with clumps forming as moisture concentrates. The person might pulse a grinder, rotate blades, or press and grind with a mortar and pestle, occasionally scraping the bowl to keep material moving.
finished_description: End state: ground almonds (almond meal) — dry, pale beige to tan; particles range from fine powder to small irregular crumbs. Shapes are irregular; no shells or large chunks. Texture crumbly to powdery, loose and non-sticky, with minimal moisture (may clump if oily). The person might be transferring to a bowl or measuring cup, sifting for uniformity, or incorporating into batter or dough.

initial_description: Initial state: peppercorns are whole, roughly spherical to oval, about 3–5 mm across; colors range black, white, green, or pink; hard, dry, and smooth or slightly wrinkled. They sit loose in a bowl, grinder hopper, or mortar and pestle, often in a small cluster. When starting, the person may pick up a few peppercorns and load them into the grinder or mortar, aligning them to begin crushing.
transition_description: Mid-crush, peppercorns are partly fractured: jagged shards and coarse granules mingle with some still-intact kernels. Surfaces are rough and angular; colors range from deep brown to charcoal; a fine pepper dust forms on the mixture. Oils from the pepper flash a subtle sheen. The person uses a mortar and pestle, applying steady pressure and rotating or pounding to guide fragments toward finer consistency.
finished_description: End state: Ground pepper—powder to granular particles, irregular shapes, dark gray to black (varies by pepper type), with a fine, dusty texture or slightly clumped from oils. The person may be pouring pepper into a shaker, transferring to a jar, or wiping the counter after measuring.

initial_description: Initial state: a pineapple intact or pre-cut, on a clean surface. Shape is oval to cylindrical; size about 6–12 inches tall and 2–4 inches in diameter. Exterior rind is rough, patterned brown-gold; green crown on top. Flesh beneath is firm, pale yellow; core is visible and rigid. If peeled, the exposed flesh is glossy and dense. The person beginning crushing might wash, trim the crown, and grasp the fruit to apply initial pressure.
transition_description: Intermediate state: irregular, fibrous pulp with partial liquid. Chunks have broken into granules and mash; mass is wet, sticky, and dripping. Color shifts to pale to bright yellow with juice pooling; seeds scattered and sometimes visible. Texture ranges from chunky, grainy slurry to smooth, cohesive mush as pressure continues. The person may be pressing, mashing with a masher or spoon, pulsing a blender, or squeezing the pieces to release juice, occasionally scraping the sides.
finished_description: End state of crushing pineapple: a uniform golden-yellow pulp with mostly small fragments and released juice. Shape is irregular and mash-like; most pieces are under a few millimeters, with fine fibrous strands visible. Color ranges from pale to bright yellow; texture is semi-liquid to thick mush, sometimes smooth if well-pureed, with some juice separation. The person finished crushing might be scooping or spooning the pulp, straining juice, or proceeding to cook, blend, or canning.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole onion on a cutting board, papery outer skin intact. Shape round to slightly oval; diameter about 4–6 cm. Color: tan-yellow skin; interior white and crisp with pale translucent layers. Texture firm and dense; surface dry with a few loose scales. The person is just starting: gripping the onion and peeling away the outer skin and trimming the root, before any cutting or crushing.
transition_description: Mid-crush, onion appears as irregular chunks and slivers, with some pieces flattened or smeared while others stay chunky. Juices pool and form a translucent, slick slurry that coats surfaces. Color shifts toward pale white/translucent, with a faint hue from the skin; purple onions may show a pinkish tint. Texture spans coarse granules to a soft paste, with visible pulp and a shiny, moist coating. The person is pressing, smashing, and scraping with a utensil, rotating or regrouping pieces.
finished_description: End state: crushed onion appears as a moist mound of irregular granules about 1–3 mm, or a pale translucent paste if finely crushed. Color ranges white to pale yellow with hints of purple from skin; released juices give a glossy, sticky surface. Texture is juicy, not smooth. The person finished with crushing may be adding it to a pan, stirring it into a dish, or transferring it to a bowl and cleaning tools.

initial_description: Initial state: raw chicken pieces (breasts, thighs, or drumsticks) on a clean surface. They are pale pink with whitish fat, some skin, and a light, glistening surface moisture; pieces vary in shape and thickness, not yet seasoned or battered. The preparer is at the prep stage: selecting pieces, patting them dry with paper towels, and arranging them within reach, with bowls of flour/seasoning nearby to begin coating.
transition_description: Mid-coating, the chicken shows uneven, partially adhered layers. The pieces remain the same size and shape but with visible batter or crumb clinging to some faces while others stay bare. The surface is wet or tacky, with a glossy or milky film, sometimes speckled or streaked, and thicker patches where coating collects. Edges may have ridges or drips; droplets hang from the surface. The worker dips, turns, shakes off excess, and smooths the coat with a spatula or tongs.
finished_description: End state: chicken pieces fully coated with a uniform, adherent layer; no bare spots; edges smoothly wrapped; surface texture either smooth batter or crumbly breading; thickness even and the piece remains consistent in shape with a slight increase in girth; color pale beige to light tan depending on coating mix. The person finished might place coated pieces on a tray or rack, ready for frying or baking, or preheat the oven or fryer.

initial_description: Initial state: raw potato tubers, shapes from round to elongated, sizes from small to medium/large; skin brown/tan, earthy with surface dirt; rough, thin skin with visible eyes; flesh pale white inside when peeled; surface dry to slightly damp, uncoated. The person beginning coating is likely selecting tubers, washing/scrubbing off soil, inspecting for blemishes, and patting dry before any coating is applied.
transition_description: Mid-coating, potato pieces bear a damp, uneven layer that glistens where batter or spice clings. Surfaces appear swollen, with pockets of moisture and tiny air bubbles; some areas remain bare or thin while others are thickened. The coating shows mottled color—cream, tan, or pale gold—under a translucent film. The cook is dipping, rolling, and pressing to encourage adhesion, while tapping off excess and repositioning pieces for more uniform coverage.
finished_description: End state: Potatoes are evenly coated with a uniform crust that adheres firmly and remains crisp when cooked. Shapes stay wedges or chunks with consistent size; exterior color ranges from light golden to deep brown, depending on coating; surface shows crisp, textured coating. Interiors stay tender. The person finished with coating potato is arranging coated pieces on a baking sheet or into hot oil for frying, ready to cook or monitor cooking.

initial_description: Initial state: fish are uncoated, intact, and laid out on a clean surface. They vary from small to large, with natural skin colors and visible scales; bodies are elongated with a rounded cross-section. Some moisture on the skin. Nearby: coating material in a bowl, brushes or sprayer, and gloves. The beginner is just preparing—picking up a fish with tongs, positioning it, or inspecting it before any coating is applied.
transition_description: During coating in progress, the fish shows irregular coverage: patches of coating adhere to the surface with visible gaps and uneven edges along the contours. The layer ranges from thin to moderately thick, and the surface texture shifts from smooth flesh to a grainy or batter-like feel; color blends from fish tone to breadcrumb/batter hues, sometimes with a glossy wet patch. The handler applies by dipping, rolling, patting, or brushing, turning pieces for even contact and reapplying to areas.
finished_description: End state: evenly coated fish fillets with a uniform batter or breadcrumb crust, intact shape and size, surface golden-brown and crisp, slightly glossy, speckled with seasonings, no bare spots; edges crisp, coating adherent, texture firm. The person finished with coating fish may proceed to cook them—placing on a preheated pan, fryer, or oven rack, and overseeing frying or baking to finish browning.

initial_description: Initial state: a single uncoated apple with smooth, intact skin, generally round-to-oval, medium size (roughly 7–8 cm in diameter). Color reflects the cultivar (red, green, yellow, or mixed) with natural gloss and speckling. Surface is dry and clean; no coating or texture changes yet. The preparer is likely washing and drying the fruit, inspecting for bruises, and gripping it steady in one hand as they begin setup.
transition_description: While coating is underway, the fruit shows an irregular, wet glaze. The shape remains apple-like, but the surface has uneven thickness, with slightly raised ridges where the layer pools. Apparent size appears slightly larger due to coating buildup. The color ranges from the underlying red/green to translucent gloss with tinted patches; finish is shiny and sticky. Drips may form at lower areas. The worker rotates or swirls the apple on a stick, brushes or sprays, and blots excess.
finished_description: Final coated apple: a glossy, uniform shell fully encasing the fruit, with a smooth, tight surface. Color matches the coating (dark chocolate, caramel, or candy shell), with no exposed skin; the shape remains roughly the original oval, lightly rounded ends; no drips or lumps. The coating feels firm to the bite. In finishing, the worker dries/cools the apples on a rack or parchment, then transfers to packaging or display.

initial_description: Uncoated tofu pieces readied for coating: pale ivory blocks, firm to extra-firm, pressed and drained; cut into uniform cubes or slabs about 1–2 cm (½–¾ in) thick; smooth surface with residual moisture; no batter or crumb yet. Pieces arranged on a tray or cutting board; hands or tongs hover as the cook begins—patting dry or placing pieces near bowls of flour/cornstarch and spices, ready to dredge.
transition_description: Intermediate coating state: tofu pieces (cubed or sliced) retain shape and size, but are enrobed in a thin to medium, wet, glossy batter that clings. Some areas are fully coated while others show exposed blocks; edges may bulge with uneven thickness. Color ranges from pale beige to light brown, with specks from spices. Batter may drip down sides, forming pools. The person turns, lifts, and shakes off excess batter for even coverage on a tray.
finished_description: End state: Tofu pieces uniformly coated with an even layer, maintaining original size and shape. Exterior forms a crisp crust (or glossy glaze) with a golden to amber color, no bare spots, and a firm, cohesive texture that adheres to the surface. The finished cook may be transferring the coated pieces to a baking sheet or skillet, then baking/frying, or plating them for serving.

initial_description: Initial state: A standard loaf, about 20 cm long and 10 cm wide, rests on a clean work surface, crust dry and pale tan with light flour dust. A small dish holds glaze, oil, or melted butter; a pastry brush or spoon hovers above. The first contact with the surface leaves a thin, translucent film or tiny specks, barely changing color. The person is just starting to apply, using light brushing, dabbing, or a gentle drag across the top.
transition_description: Mid-coating, bread shows a wet, tacky film with a variable gloss from translucent to matte as glaze or spray spreads. The loaf shape remains, but edges often have uneven coverage and slight pooling in creases or along the bottom. Thickness varies: thin patches, thicker specks, and visible brush strokes or spray overlaps. Hands manipulate the surface by tilting the tray, rotating the bread, and brushing, spraying, or sprinkling to even the layer.
finished_description: End state of coated bread: a loaf or rolls with a set surface of the coating. The crust shows color, golden to amber, with a smooth or lightly textured finish depending on coating (glaze, butter wash, seeds, sugar). The coating forms a thin, glossy or matte layer that is crisp or slightly tacky to touch, preserving the bread’s shape and size. The person may be cooling the loaf on a rack or placing it into packaging after coating.

initial_description: Initial state: raw, uncoated shrimp that are cleaned and deveined, with tails left on or off per recipe. They’re about 1.5–2.5 inches long, gently curved, cylindrical in shape, and translucent gray-pink. The surface is moist and slick, with intact shells or peels. On a prep tray, they are spaced and ready for handling. The cook starting coating will wash or pat dry, and line up shrimp while assembling bowls of egg wash and dredge.
transition_description: During coating, shrimp appear partially encased with a glossy, wet film that clings unevenly to the curved surfaces, imparting a pale batter tint. The surface shows variable thickness: thin edges, thicker centers; visible drips and rivulets of batter or breadcrumbs. Textures range from tacky to slightly stiff as batter begins to set; bubbles or air pockets may mark the surface. The handler uses gentle motions—dipping, rolling, or turning—to maintain adhesion and prevent pooling.
finished_description: End state: shrimp fully encased in an even coating with no bare skin. The coating covers the entire curved surface, seals edges, and sits at uniform thickness. Color is uniform within the outer layer, typically pale beige to golden brown after cooking, with a crisp breadcrumb texture or smooth, glossy batter depending on method. The person finishes by arranging coated shrimp on a rack or tray, ready for frying or baking.

initial_description: Initial state: a cooled cake resting on a turntable, ready for coating. Shape is round or rectangular to match the pan; diameter and height approximate baked loaf/layers; top is flat, sides vertical, surface color pale beige from the crumb; texture firm yet yielding, surface dry and crumb-free. No icing or glaze present. The beginner is centering the cake on the turntable and using a serrated knife to level the top.
transition_description: Mid-coating states show a cake partially enveloped by a glossy or opaque layer that is still wet. The surface may be slick, streaked, or marbled, with visible runnels and drips along the sides. The coating thickness varies, leaving ridges where pans or spatula have pressed. Colors range from pale to deep glaze, darker at thicker areas. The baker may tilt or rotate the cake, brush, pour, or smooth with a spatula to even the layer and release air bubbles.
finished_description: End state: a uniformly coated cake with a smooth, glossy exterior; base shape preserved (round or rectangular) and only slightly enlarged by the coating; color uniform across surface (e.g., chocolate brown or pale glaze); coating firm with clean edges, minimal texture, and no drips or bare spots; even thickness and a sealed finish. The person finished might be cooling on a rack, inspecting for defects, trimming excess coating, or packaging for service.

initial_description: Initial state: an uncoated onion bulb, intact papery skin, dry and firm. Shape is oval to round; diameter typically 3 to 6 cm; flesh pale white beneath the skin. Surface shows natural grooves and a root end. No batter, crumb, or liquid present yet. When starting, the person is prepping: peeling away the papery skin, trimming the top and root ends, and arranging a coating setup (bowl of flour, seasonings, and batter) nearby.
transition_description: During coating, the onion shows partial coverage with a shimmering, wet film that varies in thickness and follows the rounded contours. Surfaces are uneven: slick, glossy patches beside matte, speckled areas from irregular adhesion. Color may tint the film (pale yellow to light brown), with droplets pooling in crevices. Odor intensifies and the surface feels tacky. The worker applies coating by dipping, spraying, or brushing, turning the onion to improve contact.
finished_description: Final state: onion rings or slices fully coated with an even, adherent batter or breading. Outer crust uniform in thickness, lightly textured, color from pale beige to golden brown (darker if fried). Surface crisp or dry with no exposed onion. Pieces are uniform in size and shape for even cooking. The person finished with coating may move them to frying or baking, or lay them on a tray to rest before cooking.

initial_description: Initial state: A solid, rectangular stick of butter (about 4×1.5×1 inches), pale yellow with a uniform color and a smooth surface. It is firm, but yields slightly under pressure if softened; consistency ranges from hard to slightly pliable depending on temperature. No coating is present. The preparer unpacks the package, selects or slices a portion, and places it at the coating station to begin handling.
transition_description: During coating, the butter piece presents as a partially coated block. Shape remains rectangular or rounded, but surfaces show uneven thickness; edges may be rounded from pressing. The coating creates a thin, tacky film that is glossy where moist and duller where dry. Color shifts to pale beige with speckled or tinted patches. Texture ranges from smooth, slick to slightly grainy, with visible ridges where it clings. Handling involves brushing, rolling, or turning to apply and remove excess.
finished_description: End state: a uniformly enrobed butter piece preserving its original block shape; size unchanged aside from a slight edge rounding. Outer coating color varies with the material (golden breadcrumbs, herb flecks, sesame specks, or sugar glaze). Texture ranges from crisp/grainy to glossy. The butter is largely hidden beneath a complete coating. The person finished with coating might be chilling the piece to set, then slicing, portioning, or readying it for bake.

initial_description:
- Initial state: Dry pasta pieces (various shapes) are uncoated, pale cream, matte surface; sizes depend on type.
- When starting to coat: A thin translucent film or small droplets begin to appear on surfaces as the coating agent is introduced.
- What the beginner is doing: They tilt a bowl or pan, drizzle or pour oil or sauce, and gently toss or stir to initiate adhesion, not yet fully coated.
transition_description: During coating in progress, pasta shows an uneven, wet film: a thin, glossy veil with color streaks where sauce pools in bends and curves, with thicker patches on some surfaces. The coating is viscous and slightly tacky, with droplets clinging to ridges and crevices. Surface appears translucent with reflections, sometimes small clumps forming as ingredients emulsify. The person is tossing, stirring with tongs or a spatula, tilting the pan, and redistributing sauce to even out coverage, avoiding excessive pooling.
finished_description: End state: pasta evenly coated with sauce, glossy and slightly viscous, surface color uniform to the sauce; no dry patches, shape remains intact; each strand or shape has a thin, adherent glaze that highlights ridges; slight stickiness indicates moisture. The person finished with coating pasta is likely plating or tossing it in a pan, transferring to a dish, garnishing with herbs or cheese, and serving.

initial_description: Initial state: one ripe banana, peeled, about 6 inches long, curved. Exterior is yellow with a few brown speckles; flesh inside is pale cream and reasonably firm, not yet mushy. For a beginner, they place the peeled banana in a bowl, grip it with one hand, and use a fork or spoon to press down, starting to break it into pieces.
transition_description: During mashing, the banana presents a patchwork of textures. Some fragments remain chunky while others have blurred into a creamy paste; the mass forms irregular ridges and swirls as it’s pressed, stirred, and folded with a fork or masher. Color shifts from bright yellow to duller, tan-brown in spots where oxidation occurs. The surface is moist and slightly glossy, with small moisture beads and occasional lumps that break apart under continued pressing.
finished_description: End state: a pale yellow, uniform, creamy banana mash with small specks; smooth or gently chunky paste, scoopable and able to hold a soft mound in a bowl or on a plate. Color ranges from bright banana to light beige. Consistency is thick enough to keep its shape but soft and spreadable. The person finished mashing might be scooping it into a bowl, spreading on toast, or whisking into batter.

initial_description: Initial state: raw potatoes, firm and whole, often with tan-brown skin; flesh pale white to yellow. Cut into rough chunks about 2–4 cm; skins may be on or peeled. Surfaces dry, hard, and cool to the touch; no softness yet. What the person is doing: peeling or trimming, then dicing into chunks and adding them to a pot of water to begin boiling, prepping for mashing.
transition_description: Mid-mash, the mass is speckled with lumps; fine, glossy puree patches mix with chunky islands. Color is pale yellow-beige with bits of skin for texture. Surfaces range from smooth, slippery to grainy and ridged; small air pockets create a quilted look. The mass clings slightly to the masher and spoon, forming ribbons as it is pressed, scraped, and folded. Steam hints at moisture release as warmth softens the pieces in the pot.
finished_description: End state: mashed potatoes are creamy and smooth with a uniform texture; pale ivory to light yellow from butter or milk; surface may be glossy. They hold a soft mound or spoonful on a plate and can be airy fluffy or dense cream depending on mixing. The person is likely serving or plating, perhaps transferring to a dish, topping with butter and seasoning, or tasting for salt.

initial_description: Two ripe avocado halves sit skin-on on a cutting board, pit removed. Skins are dark green to near-black; flesh is pale green to yellow, slightly glossy, with the area near the cut showing a smooth surface and gentle give when pressed. The person grips a spoon or fork over the halves, poised to scoop or pry the flesh from the skin, ready to mash.
transition_description: Intermediate state: a green-yellow paste with a mix of smooth and chunky textures. Some sections are silky and uniform; others chunky with pea-sized lumps. Color ranges from bright green to olive; slight browning at edges may appear. The surface bears fork or masher ridges; streaks and swirls reflect partial mixing. The person is pressing, mashing, and folding with a fork or masher, scraping the bowl sides and rotating to distribute texture.
finished_description: End state: a smooth to slightly chunky green paste, uniform color from pale to mid-green, creamy and spreadable. In a bowl or on a surface, a small mound roughly the size of a fist, or a thin, even layer a few millimeters thick. After finishing, they may spread it on toast, scoop for chips, or mix in lime juice and salt.

initial_description: On a cutting board lie three to five garlic cloves: ivory-white, teardrop-shaped, about 1–2 cm long, with thin papery skins. They feel firm, dry, and smooth. The person has just begun: picking up a clove, holding it between fingers, and lightly pressing it with the flat side of a knife or their thumb to brace it, initiating the mashing setup.
transition_description: As mashing proceeds, garlic breaks into irregular shards and flattened fragments. The pieces vary from crumbly granules to small, damp shreds, releasing pale, translucent juice. The mass becomes a glossy, slightly sticky cohesive mass with visible fibrous strands; oil droplets bead on the surface. The mover rotates, presses, and drags the pestle or spoon, scraping the sides to rework clumps and promote further breakdown. Moisture and aroma intensify.
finished_description: End state: a cohesive, pale yellow to off-white garlic paste—smooth, glossy, and without discernible chunks; a fine, almost pureed texture with a slight sheen from released oils. It sits as a small, compact mound or smear on the surface. What might they be doing: transferring to a pan or bowl, scraping with a spatula, or whisking into oil, butter, or other ingredients to start cooking or flavoring.

initial_description: At the start, tomatoes are whole, round to slightly oblong, red and smooth-skinned; sizes range from small plum to fist-sized, with firm yet yielding flesh and a damp surface. They may have stems attached. The starter might rinse, trim the stem, and place them on a cutting board, poised to be crushed.
transition_description: During mashing, the tomato mass is uneven, with a mix of small granules, irregular chunks, and ribbons of flesh. The paste is wet and glossy, with juice pooling and seeds dispersed. Colors vary from bright red to slightly darker pink/red where pulp is exposed. The texture ranges from coarse to semi-smooth, with fibrous strands and soft pockets of liquid. The mashing tool is pressing, twisting, and scraping the flesh against a surface, breaking apart pieces as they release juice.
finished_description: End state: a smooth, homogeneous tomato puree or sauce with no visible chunks. Shape: amorphous (mound or pool); size: a uniform mass, not discrete pieces. Color: bright to deep red; surface glossy. Consistency: thick but pourable; seeds/skin largely integrated or strained out. After finishing, the person might cook it into sauce, simmer it in a pot, or ladle it into jars.

initial_description: Initial state: whole, intact beans in a bowl or bag, not yet mashed. Shape: small ovals, about 5–12 mm long. Color: varies by variety—tan, brown, red, black, or mottled. Surface: smooth, hard skins; no visible crushing. Consistency: firm and dry (dry beans) or plump and hydrated if canned. What they’re doing: selecting/picking beans, transferring them to a masher or grinder to begin preparation, possibly rinsing or inspecting for defects.
transition_description: During mashing, beans fragment into irregular chunks and skins, yielding a mixture that ranges from chunky to mostly paste. Color varies from light tan to brown with specks; the surface is damp, slightly glossy, and sticky. Remaining skins create uneven lumps; some fragments are smooth, others still coarse. The mass may release liquid or oil and cling to utensils. The person presses, crushes, stirs, and scrapes the sides with a masher or fork, inching toward a uniform consistency.
finished_description: End state: a cohesive, paste-like mass of mashed beans, with no whole beans visible. Texture ranges from smooth to chunky, depending on method; color typically tan to brown; surface may be glossy or satin; consistent in thickness, scoopable or spreadable, forming a soft mound when thumped. Size/shape: a compact blob or patty that holds its form. A person finished mashing beans might be portioning or plating, spreading on tortillas, or seasoning and serving.

initial_description: Initial state: a solid, cold butter block with pale yellow color, smooth surface, and firm, shape-retentive form. It is rectangular or irregularly cubed, roughly a few centimeters across (like a standard stick or pat), not yet softened or mashed. The person is just beginning: gripping or lifting the block and placing it on a cutting board or dish, fingers poised to apply light pressure to start mashing.
transition_description: In progress, softened butter fragments into irregular chunks, ranging from pea-sized to smear-like pieces. The mass is pale yellow with white specks, becoming gradually more cohesive but still uneven. The surface shifts from matte to a light gloss as fat droplets emulsify and the moisture releases. The texture may be crumbly pockets, then a pliable paste that can be spread. The person uses a fork, spoon, or pastry blender, pressing and turning, scraping the bowl to break down lumps.
finished_description: End state: a soft, spreadable, cohesive mass of butter, pale yellow to light gold, with a glossy surface and uniform, smooth texture; no visible chunks or grain. Shape is a small mound or disk that yields easily to a light press. The person may be placing or smoothing the mashed butter onto a surface, into a container, or readying it for spreading on bread or for cooking.

initial_description: Initial state: whole chickpeas sit in a small bowl, pale beige to tan, about 7–10 mm each, with smooth, slightly ridged skins and a firm, rounded shape. They may be dry if uncooked or softly cooked according to prep. A person stands ready, holding a wooden spoon or pestle above the bowl, poised to press down, hands near the chickpeas, signaling the mash is about to begin.
transition_description: Mid-mash chickpeas show an uneven mixture: some beans crushed into chunky fragments while others remain whole, with irregular shapes. Textures range from coarse, grainy bits to soft, paste-like pockets; color is pale beige with slightly yellowish tones. Surfaces look matte and damp, with sticky streaks where moisture concentrates. The mashing motion involves pressing and turning with a fork or pestle, occasionally scraping the bowl to blend without smoothing into a full paste.
finished_description: End state: a smooth to slightly chunky paste of mashed chickpeas—pale beige to light tan—with no whole pieces visible. Texture is creamy, spreadable or scoopable, often with tiny soft particles; moisture and oil yield a glossy or matte surface. Shape is a uniform mass that holds together but lacks discrete pieces. The person finished might be spreading it as hummus on bread, dipping with vegetables, or forming it into falafel/patties.

initial_description: Initial state: vivid red, glossy strawberries, mostly whole with green tops; seeds speckle the skin; sizes range ~2–3 cm; firm to slightly soft, surfaces dewy from washing. They're arranged on a cutting board. The starter is selecting and positioning a berry, stabilizing it with a hand, and lightly grasping a masher or fork, preparing to apply gentle downward pressure to begin mashing.
transition_description: During mashing, the strawberry mixture shows pulp of varying particle sizes: irregular fragments, broken fibers, and pools of juice. Colors range pink to deep red with a glossy, wet surface. Texture shifts from chunky to more cohesive, partially liquefied paste as crushing continues, with small clumps and some seeds still visible. The person uses a masher or fork, pressing, crushing, and stirring to release juice and blend solids.
finished_description: End state: a glossy, thick red strawberry puree with a uniform color and light translucence; no large chunks, small seed specks visible; texture is smooth-to-pulpy, forming a slight mound in the bowl. After finishing, the person might scoop or pour the mash into a container or dish, spread it as a sauce or filling, or begin mixing it with sugar or liquid ingredients.

initial_description: Initial state: berries are whole and intact—round to oval, small to medium, with smooth, glossy skins in red, purple, or blue hues; stems attached or nearby; skin firm and lightly dewy. The person starting to mash might be picking up berries, rinsing them, removing stems, and placing them in a bowl or mortar, then applying gentle pressure with fingers or a muddler to begin crushing.
transition_description: During the process, the berries break into fragments, releasing juices that mingle with pulp. The mix shifts from speckled whole fruit to a chunky slurry; colors deepen to rich purples or reds with a glossy, wet sheen. Seeds and small bits remain visible; some liquid pools separate. The texture ranges from lumpy to semi-smooth as the mass is mashed or pressed, creating a sticky surface. The person grips a masher or spoon, twisting, pressing, and scraping the bowl.
finished_description: End state: mashed berries form a cohesive mass—either chunky or smooth, occupying a bowl or jar. Color ranges deep red to purple, often glossy, with visible seeds and small fragments. Consistency is thick and spreadable, not liquid, sometimes uniform, sometimes lumpy. After finishing, the person may scoop the mash into a container, spread it on a surface, or wipe the tools clean.

initial_description: Initial state: Raw eggs either in shell or cracked into a bowl. If intact, eggs are small to medium sized, oval shells (white, brown, or speckled). If cracked into the bowl, the whites are clear, thin, and glossy; the yolk is a round, intact globe hovering in a pool of translucent liquid. The starting action: the person positions the egg, taps it on the edge, and cracks it so contents begin to separate from shell and settle in bowl.
transition_description: Interim mashing shows a pale yellow mixture with both broken yolk fragments and dissolved portions. Visuals: small curds, chunky halos, and wispy strands; color ranges from light cream to slightly darker yellow; texture moves from grainy to soft, with a glossy surface in some areas and matte in others; air bubbles create a light froth. The person uses a fork or masher, pressing, folding, and scraping, rotating the bowl to incorporate and reduce lumps.
finished_description: End state: a pale yellow to ivory, smooth or softly crumbly mash of eggs with no shell fragments. Moist, cohesive but not runny; color uniform with small white specks from the whites. Texture ranges from fine paste to chunky crumble, size varies from a small scoop to a compact patty. After mashing, the person might mix in mayo and seasonings, then spread on bread or use as the filling for egg salad.

initial_description: Initial state: raw cauliflower florets, white and compact, with pale green stems. Buds are tight and fine-grained, surface dry and firm to touch; sizes range from small to medium. No color change or mushiness yet. The person beginning to mash may trim leaves, rinse the head, and break florets into rough chunks, then place them in a bowl with a masher or fork, ready to mash.
transition_description: Intermediate mashing stage: in a mixing bowl, cauliflower shows a mix of textures as progress continues. Some florets are crushed to small granules, others remain irregular chunks; the surface is uneven with pockets of coarser mash and smoother, paste-like areas. Colors stay pale white to ivory with a light moisture sheen. The person uses a fork or potato masher, pressing, twisting, and scraping the sides, occasionally regrouping pieces to even texture.
finished_description: End state: a pale ivory, creamy to fluffy mound of mashed cauliflower with uniform, fine grains and no large lumps. Texture ranges from smooth to slightly chunky depending on mashing; surface matte to lightly glossy; typically warm. Portion size resembles a scoop or cupful, shaped into a rounded mound for serving. The person finished may be seasoning, stirring with a spoon, or transferring to a dish or bowl for plating.

initial_description: Initial state: a solid block of butter (stick or slab), cool and rigid, with clean, straight edges. Size varies—roughly a few centimeters across; color from pale to medium yellow; texture firm and smooth, with little sheen. It may be unwrapped or partially exposed in foil. The person starting the process might be unwrapping the package, snapping off a chunk, or placing the butter in a pan and turning the burner on to begin heating.
transition_description: Intermediate state: solid blocks partially melted, with sharp edges softening; a central pool of clear, glossy liquid surrounded by pale yellow chunks. The surface shows a two-tone texture—opaque solid pieces and translucent butter—while small bubbles form and rise. Color shifts toward golden as fat releases. Steam wisps rise and the mixture glistens. The person is stirring or tilting the pan with a spatula, guiding heat and promoting even melt.
finished_description: End state: A smooth, uniform puddle of melted butter pooling in the pan, with a glossy golden color ranging from pale yellow to amber. It is pourable, viscous, and free of solid chunks; edges glow, surface may shine with a thin film and tiny bubbles. After melting: the person may be pouring it into batter or sauce, sautéing aromatics, greasing a pan, or using the liquid to finish a dish.

initial_description: Initial state: solid chocolate in pieces—chips, shards, or broken bars—varying from pale tan to rich brown. Pieces are firm, dry, and angular or rounded, with a smooth or slightly matte surface; no liquid seen. They sit in a heatproof bowl or on a plate, awaiting heating. The person is breaking bars into smaller chunks, measuring portions, or arranging pieces in the bowl and prepping a double boiler or microwave setup to begin warming.
transition_description: Intermediates show a mix of unmelted chips and liquid pools. Irregular, glossy ribbons of melted chocolate flow slowly around remaining lumps; edges soften into rounded mounds while centers stay thicker. Color ranges from warm brown to lighter caramel as heat penetrates; surface is satin-glossy with streaks and bubbles. Viscosity is medium-high, sometimes sheen-rich, sometimes matte as fats separate. The person stirs, folds, and scrapes the bottom, monitoring consistency and smoothing surfaces.
finished_description: Fully melted chocolate forms a smooth, glossy, uniform liquid that pools into a glossy puddle, color-rich and free of lumps or fat separation. It is pourable yet viscous, coating or drizzling evenly. The user may be pouring it onto a tray or into molds, dipping fruit or treats, brushing a thin layer, or transferring to a piping bag for decoration.

initial_description: Initial state: a solid cheese piece—block, slice, or chunk—palm-sized or smaller; flat-edged or cubed; color ranges from pale ivory to warm yellow; texture dense and hard; surface cool and firm. A beginner might place the cheese in a pan, turn on the burner, or shred/grate it into a bowl, preparing to heat.
transition_description: Intermediate melting shows irregular, partially fused masses: chunks with softened perimeters, intact cores, and expanding liquid pools. Surfaces glaze with a glossy, translucent sheen; color shifts from pale ivory to warm amber edges. Consistency ranges from soft, tacky to viscous and stringy, with occasional thin films and small bubbles breaking the surface. Shape becomes amorphous and lumpy, threads may stretch when pulled. The cook stirs, scrapes, tilts, or folds, and watches surface tension and tiny oil droplets form.
finished_description: End state: fully melted, the cheese forms a smooth, cohesive pool or sheet with a glossy surface. It is uniform in color (ivory to golden yellow, depending on type) and free of solid chunks. Viscosity ranges from pourable to slightly thick; it may form a thin film and, when stretched, a soft pull. The edges may thicken or curl as it cools. The person might pour, spread, slice, or dip with it ready to serve.

initial_description: Initial state: dry, granular sugar—white crystals—loose in a shallow, heat-safe pan. Crystals uniform in size, non-clumped, with a subtle glint. No liquid or color change yet; surface matte and grainy. The person is preparing heat: placing the pan on a burner and measuring or pouring sugar into it, readying the stove.
transition_description: In the mid-stage of melting, the crystals soften and dissolve into a pooled, translucent liquid. Unmelted granules may remain as small beads or irregular specks. The surface is glossy; bubbles form and rise as water evaporates, sometimes a light foam around the edges. Color shifts from white to pale yellow to amber with heat. The mass thickens toward a viscous, sticky syrup, and strands can form when stirred. The cook watches, stirs, and maintains heat, skimming foam as needed.
finished_description: End state: a smooth, homogeneous caramel syrup—warm amber to golden-brown, glossy surface, no crystals. Viscous and pourable, forming a thin stream or a shallow pool in the pan. The person is likely pouring or ladling the hot syrup onto parchment to cool and harden, or into a mold for candy.

initial_description: Initial state: a white, pillow-shaped marshmallow, roughly 2–4 cm across and about 1.5–2.5 cm tall, with a smooth, slightly glossy surface and a light starch coating. It is soft, springy, and easily compressed, retaining its form. When melting begins, the outer surface yields slightly, forming tiny dimples and a faint tackiness as heat interacts with the exterior. The beginner typically holds the marshmallow on a stick or utensil and positions it near a gentle heat source to start.
transition_description: Intermediate states: a marshmallow on a stick or in a dish shows softened, partially melted mass with a gooey, translucent core and a thin, blistered crust. The surface is glossy and sticky, with bubbles and slight bubbling along the edges as heat expands air pockets. The size may subtly bulge; color shifts from pale cream to light amber at exposed edges. It may streak threads when lifted; the handler rotates or tests softness, slowly melting further.
finished_description: End state: a single smooth, glossy, cohesive puddle or sheet of marshmallow that flows under gravity; color remains white-to-ivory (slightly golden if overheated); extremely sticky but pourable; no lumps; can be stretched briefly when pulled. For the person: pouring onto a surface to coat or shape, spreading in a pan to set, or mixing with butter, cereal, or toppings, often using a spatula and letting cool.

initial_description: Initial state: a solid block of ghee, firm and cohesive, roughly the size of a thumb or small cube, with a uniform golden-yellow color ranging from pale to amber. Surface is smooth and glossy; edges may be sharp or gently rounded. The texture is dense and can feel slightly crumbly when pressed. The person begins by cutting or scooping a chunk from a tub to place in a pan.
transition_description: Mid-melt, ghee shows translucent edges while the center yields into a smooth, honey-gold pool. Chunks shrink as they swirl into a glossy liquid, with the color deepening from pale yellow to amber. The surface glitters and a few tiny bubbles rise as residual moisture escapes; the texture becomes fluid but remains slightly viscous in places. The cook tilts the pan, stirs gently, and sweeps the sides to promote even melting.
finished_description: End state: Ghee is a smooth, pourable pool, glossy golden to amber, uniform in color with no solid pieces. It flows readily, has moderate viscosity, and forms a thin surface film with a soft sheen; it clings slightly to the vessel, taking the shape of the container. Amount dictates pool size; no lumps remain. The person may be pouring it into a pan or dish, drizzling over food, or greasing cookware.

initial_description: Initial state: solid caramel pieces—blocks, chips, or coins—roughly fingertip to 2–3 cm across; color pale golden to deep amber; surface smooth and glossy; texture hard and brittle with a clean snap; no liquid present; uniform shape, no pooling. The person starting melting might be breaking the caramel into smaller pieces and placing them in a pan or bowl.
transition_description: As melting continues, caramel sits as a warm, amber pool with irregular edges. The surface is glossy and fluid but still thick, with wisps of steam and occasional bubbles. Small unmelted sugar flecks may cling to the sides, gradually dissolving as color deepens from honey to copper. The pool spreads and thins, forming a shimmering sheet that moves slowly with gentle swirls. The cook stirs, scrapes, and adjusts heat to maintain smoothness.
finished_description:
- Fully melted caramel is a smooth, glossy amber liquid—thick, pourable, and viscous. It forms a free-flowing pool or a thin film, with color from honey-gold to deep amber and a mostly uniform, bubble-free surface.  
- After melting, a person might drizzle it over desserts, dip apples, nuts, or pretzels, or spread it onto a sheet to cool into brittle.

initial_description: Initial state: jaggery in solid form as a dense lump or irregular block, roughly palm- to fist-sized, with a rough, slightly chalky surface. Color ranges golden amber to deep brown. Edges blunt; block feels hard and compact, with visible crystals. Just starting to melt: heat is applied and the outer surface shows a light gloss as the edges begin to soften. The person may be breaking the block into smaller pieces or dropping chunks into a pan.
transition_description: During melting, jaggery softens from solid blocks into a viscous, amber syrup. Irregular chunks gradually break down, take on rounded edges, and shrink as they dissolve. The liquid becomes glossy, thick, and sticky, with strands that pull when stirred. Bubbling can create a light foam on the surface. The cook typically stirs with a spoon or ladle, breaks remaining lumps, and moderates heat to keep a steady simmer and prevent scorching.
finished_description: End state: a glossy, viscous amber-to-dark-brown liquid with a smooth, lump-free surface. It forms a shallow pool or pours as a steady stream, coating the container with uniform viscosity; surface may show a few bubbles. The person finished melting jaggery is likely pouring or drizzling the syrup onto a preparation, measuring or spooning it into molds, or allowing it to cool and set.

initial_description: Initial state: a solid gelatin form—granules, a sheet, or a small block—color white to pale translucent, opaque to clear. Size ranges from a few cubic centimeters to hand-sized. Surface is smooth with defined edges; texture firm and brittle. When starting, the person typically measures and transfers gelatin into a container, then begins heating or adding liquid to dissolve, sometimes stirring as they initiate the melt.
transition_description: Mid-melt: a heterogeneous mass with partially softened chunks in a warm, translucent liquid. Edges round as the gel loosens; color remains the original tint but paler and milky in places. Viscosity is syrupy, with slow drips and occasional stringy threads; bubbles and steam hint at warmth. The person is heating gently, stirring to break lumps, and monitoring temperature, possibly scraping the bottom and adjusting heat.
finished_description: End state: a smooth, homogeneous liquid with no lumps, gently warm and pourable. It forms a shallow puddle in the container, evenly coating surfaces, and is translucent to tinted depending on color, with a glossy, viscous consistency. Next steps for the person: pour into molds or pans to set, whisk in flavors, and chill until it gels again.

initial_description: Initial state: a solid margarine block or stick, pale yellow or off-white, opaque, firm and cold to the touch. Shape is rectangular or oblong with clean edges; surface smooth and uniform; no liquid. When just starting to melt, a faint sheen may appear at the surface and a corner or edge may begin to soften. The person begins by unwrapping, placing the piece in a pan, or cutting a pat and heating gently.
transition_description: Intermediate melting margarine appears as a yellow-tinted mix of solid chunks and liquid fat in a pan. Irregular fragments float or sink, with edges softening into a translucent pool. Color shifts from pale to warmer yellow; the surface is glossy and semi-viscous, often with tiny bubbles or wisps of steam. The person typically stirs, scrapes, or tilts the pan, nudging pieces to swarm and merge.
finished_description: End state: A smooth, pourable pool of melted margarine—yellow-to-golden, glossy, and translucent at the edges. It sits liquid and uniform, often forming a shallow puddle across the pan bottom; no solid chunks remain. The person may pour it into a recipe, coat a surface, or move to add ingredients, then turn off heat.

initial_description: Initial state: mozzarella as a solid piece—round ball or flat slice—roughly 1–2 cm thick and 5–8 cm across. Color is white to pale ivory; surface smooth and glossy when cold. Texture is firm but pliable. When melting begins, the outer layer just starts to soften, showing a faint sheen while the center remains intact. A beginner might slice or tear it into smaller pieces and place them on a pan, pizza, or dish to heat gently.
transition_description: During melting, mozzarella becomes translucent white to pale ivory, with areas of runny liquid cheese and soft, elastic strands. It forms irregular blobs and puddles that stretch into thin, wispy threads when pulled. Surfaces bubble lightly, a glossy sheen appears, and edges begin to slick away from the pan. The center remains slightly firmer while the surrounding cheese spreads, thickens, and pools. The cook may stir, spread, or pull with tongs to guide viscosity and even coverage.
finished_description: End state: melted mozzarella forms a cohesive, glossy sheet or puddle across the surface, white to pale yellow with occasional golden brown specks. It is soft, gooey, and stretchy, yet can sit as a thin, even layer or pool around toppings. When lifted, it stretches into threads before settling. The person finished with melting mozzarella might be slicing and serving a cheesy slice, or lifting a gooey wedge to plate.

initial_description:
- Initial state: Shortening is a solid, waxy block or scoop, white to pale yellow, 1–4 inches across, dense, firm texture, smooth surface.

- Just starting to melt: A thin, glossy, translucent rim forms at the heated edge as the outer layer softens; center remains solid.

- What they might be doing: Cutting or scooping off a chunk and placing it in a pan or microwave to begin heating.
transition_description: Mid-melt shortening appears as a pale yellow mix of solid fragments and a glossy liquid pool. Parts soften into translucent droplets that coalesce into a slow, viscous flow; the surface is shiny and tacky, with edges curling as heat distributes. Swirls and small clumps drift within the liquid. The person stirs or scrapes with a spatula, nudging pieces to promote even melting without scorching.
finished_description: End state: a uniform, pourable liquid pool of shortening—pale yellow to light amber—with a glossy, smooth surface and no solid chunks. It spreads into a thin film or shallow puddle in the pan; shape is irregular and size depends on the amount melted. The person finished melting is likely turning off heat and pouring the liquid into a measuring cup or container, or letting it cool briefly before use.

initial_description: Initial state: solid candy pieces in varied shapes (chips, squares, discs), small to medium in size. Colors range across bright hues; surfaces are hard, dry, and non-sticky with clean, intact edges. When melting just starts, the edges may soften slightly and show a hint of translucence while the center remains solid. The person begins by placing pieces in a pan or microwave-safe bowl and applying gentle heat to start the process.
transition_description: In progress, the candy forms a warm, translucent, viscous pool with drips and small lumps still visible. The surface is glossy, with ribbons and thin strands that stretch when drawn, and bubbles rising and popping. Colors shift from pale amber to deeper gold as heat concentrates. The person stirs and scrapes the pot, watching for smoothness, testing texture with a spoon, and adjusting the heat as needed.
finished_description: End state: melted candy forms a single, smooth, glossy pool or sheet—uniform color, no lumps, consistent viscosity, edges forming thin drips or a flat coating; when cooled, it hardens to a solid, glossy sheet or disk. The person finished with melting candy is likely pouring or spreading the liquid onto parchment or into molds, then letting it set or harden.

initial_description: Initial state: Honey is mostly crystallized, forming a solid, irregular blob in its container (jar or spoon). It is amber-gold and opaque, with a frosted, matte surface. A thin, glossy film may cling to the edge, and tiny liquid pockets can be seen within the mass. The consistency is very thick and viscous. The person might place the container in warm water or gently rest a spoon, beginning to warm the honey.
transition_description: Intermediate melting honey appears as a glossy, translucent liquid with slow, irregular flow. It forms thin ribbons and small droplets that merge into a cohesive pool. Surface may show microbubbles and a delicate wrinkled skin. Color lightens from deep amber toward golden hues as heat softens structure; viscosity drops from thick syrup to a pourable, still-tacky consistency. In footage, the worker stirs, scrapes the sides, and tilts the container to observe spreading and uniformity.
finished_description: End state: a smooth, glossy amber-to-gold liquid with uniform viscosity and no lumps. It forms a shallow puddle or flows as a thin sheet, with a curved meniscus and high surface tension. Color is translucent amber; no crystallization remains. The person may be pouring or scraping melted honey into a jar, wiping the utensil, and letting it cool slightly before use.

initial_description: Initial state: cold cream in a container, appearing as a pale ivory mass or thick liquid depending on temperature. In a pan or cup, it sits as a small mound or shallow pool, uniform white and opaque with a glossy surface. The viscosity is thick and creamy, not yet fluid. The person is just about to start heating: they may lift the container to pour, or tilt a measuring cup to introduce the cream into a warm pan.
transition_description: Intermediate melting states show a pale ivory to cream color with a glossy surface and cohesive yet flowing viscosity. It forms slow, buttery ribbons when stirred; swirls and rivulets pool in the pan. Tiny bubbles appear and burst; a translucent film may form along the edges as it thins and coats the spoon. The texture remains smooth and velvety, and the liquid spreads slowly across the pan. The cook gently stirs, maintains low heat, and may scrape the bottom.
finished_description: End state: a smooth, homogeneous liquid—off-white to pale ivory, glossy and pourable, with a thin pool or ribbon on the surface. No lumps; slight surface bubbles may remain; viscous yet fluid. The person finished with melting cream is likely pouring it into a sauce, whisking it into a dish, or drizzling over a plated dessert while finishing cleanup.

initial_description: Initial state: a solid ice piece with a defined shape (cube/block or fragment), size small to medium. Color ranges from clear to milky white; surface is cold and rigid, possibly with trace internal bubbles. Only a thin, wet sheen or a few micro-drops at the surface mark the very start of melting. The person beginning melting ice might hold it in warm hands or place it into a warmer liquid to expose it to heat.
transition_description: Mid-melt ice shows a mix of solid chunks and liquid. Surfaces become irregular and rounded; edges erode and blocks fracture into smaller pieces. Color shifts from opaque blue-white to translucent ice with clear water pooled in cracks. A slick film covers the surface; slushy pockets form where warmth is near 0°C. The size diminishes as meltwater flows away. The person might warm with hands, pour warm water, or apply heat to accelerate melting.
finished_description: End state: fully melted ice becomes liquid water—colorless, transparent, free-flowing. It forms an irregular puddle or thin film that spreads under gravity, with soft, diffuse edges; surface may shimmer; viscosity near that of water; no solid fragments remain. If contained, the pool may adopt the container’s shape. The person finished with melting ice might be pouring the water away, wiping up moisture, or transferring it to a cup or reservoir.

initial_description: Initial state: peeled garlic cloves on a cutting board. Clove shape is oblong and tapered, with pale ivory skin; surface smooth and firm. Size about 1–2 cm long and 5–8 mm thick. Skin may be partially removed or intact, exposing a slightly glossy interior. The person beginning mincing is gripping a small kitchen knife with a firm hand, stabilizing a clove with the other hand, about to crack the skin or take the first cut.
transition_description: During mincing, garlic appears as a mix of fine granules and short shreds. Color is pale ivory to slightly translucent. Texture ranges from damp, crumbly to sticky paste, with tiny oil droplets. Juices pool around a mound of minced bits and some larger scraps. The person uses a rocking or straight chop, pressing and gathering scraps with the knife, scraping to bring the minced fragments into a cohesive pile.
finished_description: End state: finely minced garlic—tiny, uniform granules (generally under 2 mm), pale ivory to off-white, slightly moist and oily, soft yet crumbly, with an intense garlic aroma. No large pieces remain. The person is likely sautéing it in oil, or whisking it into a sauce or marinade.

initial_description: Initial state: a fresh ginger root with a knobby, irregular shape; brown/tan papery skin, some dirt, pale yellow-orange fibrous interior visible where peeled or cut; size around 2–4 inches long, 1–2 inches thick; texture rough and fibrous. At the outset, the person is positioning the blade over the ginger on a cutting board, one hand steadying the root while the other lifts or grips the knife, preparing to begin slicing or grating.
transition_description: Mid-mincing ginger presents irregular fragments: fine shreds and small granules with some fibrous strands still visible. Particle sizes range from about 0.5–3 mm, with occasional longer slivers. Color is pale yellow, slightly translucent, and the surface is moist and slightly sticky from released juice. Texture varies from crumbly to paste-like when pressed. The cook uses a rocking or slicing motion, guiding pieces toward the blade and scraping scraps off the board.
finished_description: End state: Minced ginger appears as tiny, irregular granules about 1–2 mm, uniform in size, pale yellow to beige, with a moist, soft, slightly fibrous texture. The pieces are distinct yet cohesive enough to pour or scoop; no large shards remain. The cook is likely transferring the minced ginger to a pan or bowl, scraping into a hot pan to sauté, or whisking it into a sauce or marinade.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole onion, peeled of its papery skin, with pale, translucent inner tissue. Shape is bulbous and roughly spherical, 4–6 cm diameter, with concentric white to pale yellow layers. The surface is smooth and firm. On a cutting board, the cook has just cut away the ends and laid the onion in halves or quarters, knife in hand, paused before the first slice begins.
transition_description: Intermediate minced onion state: a heterogeneous pile of irregular granules and fine shreds, ranging from wisps to tiny cubes (often brunoise-like). Sizes vary from a few millimeters down to microscopic grains; color ranges from opaque white to translucent pale purple as moisture is released. The texture is crisp, juicy, and slightly sticky, with slick onion juice on the board. The person alternates rocking and pressing the knife, gathering, and re-chopping to refine cohesion.
finished_description: End state: minced onion appears as uniform, very small pieces (about 1–2 mm), translucent white with pale purple flecks, slightly glossy and evenly moist. Texture is grainy yet soft. The person finished with mincing may be transferring the minced onion to a hot pan to sauté, or adding it to a bowl or dish, perhaps scraping the board or wiping the knife.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole shallot with dry papery skin, small teardrop bulb, tan-brown exterior with faint purple streaks, firm and compact. It remains unpeeled; the root and tip ends intact. On a cutting board, a knife is ready; the person begins by peeling away a thin outer layer and trimming the ends, stabilizing the shallot with their other hand before mincing.
transition_description: During mincing, shallot pieces become tiny, irregular bits about 1–3 mm across, ranging from translucent white to pale lilac, with shiny, moist surfaces. The texture shifts from chunky to semismooth; some fibers remain visible. The cook uses a rocking knife motion, chopping and scraping the pile toward a center, occasionally regrouping with a bench scraper for continued mincing.
