transition_description: Mid-fry, beef shows a developing brown crust from Maillard browning, with edges curling and surface ridges forming. Exterior shifts from pinkish to tan and golden-brown; fat renders, shimmering and pooling. Juices steam and small bubbles rise as moisture escapes. The cook flips and moves pieces with tongs for even contact, separates clumps to prevent sticking, and continues searing all sides.
finished_description: End state of frying beef: exterior develops a browned Maillard crust and crisp surface, with slight oil sheen; shape is compact and slightly shrunk; size reduced modestly; color ranges from golden-brown to deep-brown crust with a uniformly cooked interior that is firm and moist, gray-brown inside depending on doneness. After frying, the cook rests briefly, then plates or slices the beef, drains excess fat, and serves with sides or sauce.

initial_description: Initial state (just starting): Vegetable pieces are raw, cut into uniform sizes (dice, slices, or julienne), with bright natural colors (orange carrot, green pepper, white onion). Surfaces are glistening from moisture; edges are sharp and intact; no browning or softening yet. They sit in a thin, evenly spread layer of oil in a preheated pan. The cook is about to add or has just added the vegetables, giving a gentle shake to spread them in a single layer.
transition_description: Mid-fry vegetables lie in hot oil, pieces irregularly sized as they soften; edges brown and blister. Color shifts from bright to toasted hues; surfaces appear glossy with oil, moisture shimmering and steam rising. Gentle sizzle and occasional bubbles around pieces indicate moisture evaporation; pieces may curl or flatten as they reposition. The cook uses a spatula or tongs to stir, turn, or spread evenly, adjust heat, and keep pieces separated to prevent sticking.
finished_description: End state: vegetables are golden to deep bronze, with a crisp exterior and tender interior. They retain recognizable shape, though edges may curl or blister; surfaces glisten with a light oil sheen. Size is slightly reduced from moisture loss; interior remains moist but cooked through. Texture: crisp outside, soft inside, with caramelized edges. After frying, the cook drains on paper towels and plates or seasons/tosses them for serving.

initial_description: Initial state: raw shrimp, peeled or with shells, about 2–3 inches, translucent gray and glossy. They’re curved and moist. In a hot pan with oil, the surface shimmers and tiny bubbles form around the edges as the shrimp first contact heat. A beginner’s action: heating the oil and lowering the shrimp into a single layer, using tongs or a spatula.
transition_description: Mid-fry, shrimp sit in sizzling oil, curling into a loose C as protein contracts. Exterior turns pink-orange with light browning at the edges; surface moisture evaporates, forming a thin crisp crust while the interior thickens and becomes more opaque. Size shrinks slightly; the texture transitions from soft to firm with a gentle snap. The cook uses tongs to rotate, ensure even contact, regulate oil temp, and move pieces to avoid crowding.
finished_description: End state: fried shrimp appear pink-to-orange and opaque, with a curled, plump shape. They may be slightly smaller due to shrinkage. Exterior is crisp and golden-brown if breaded/battered; unbreaded versions are crisp and evenly colored. Interior is firm and tender, not rubbery. They are drained on paper towels and plated, tails on or off, and ready to serve with sauce or lemon.

initial_description: Initial state: Ginger cut into thin coins or matchsticks; flesh pale yellow, skin tan, irregular shapes about 0.3–0.8 cm thick and a few cm long; pieces feel firm and fibrous. In a shallow pan, oil glistens and tiny bubbles form around them; faint sizzle just starts. Ginger sits in a single layer, surface perhaps slightly moist. The cook uses tongs to lower the pieces into the hot oil, keeping them apart.
transition_description: As ginger heats, slices soften and bend, edges curling and skins loosening from the core. Slices become translucent in places, with moisture beads glistening on the surface; the pieces may shrink slightly and soften in thickness. The texture shifts from firm to yielding, fibers loosening and splitting along the grain. Oil sizzles around fragments; tiny hiss-pop events indicate moisture release. The cook stirs, tilts the pan, and adjusts heat for even contact.
finished_description: End state: ginger pieces are golden amber and crisp, with a dry, brittle texture and a toasty aroma. Slices may curl and shrink slightly; centers are firm but not soggy. Color ranges from light honey to deep amber. The cook drains excess oil on paper towels and plates the fried ginger, ready to sprinkle with salt or add to a dish.

initial_description: Initial state: bright green okra pods, whole or halved, about 3–4 inches long, with five ridges and tapered ends, smooth marbled skin and a slight fuzzy feel; firm to the touch, surface moist but not wet; mucilage intact inside. The oil in the pan is heating to shimmer but not yet smoking. The cook is trimming the ends and patting the pods dry before placing them in the hot oil.
transition_description: During frying, okra pods remain roughly elongated and may curl as heat hits, shrinking slightly. The surface shifts from bright green to olive with a glossy oil sheen, and small blisters form where the coating lifts. Edges turn tan and crisp while the centers stay tender. A steady sizzle and steam indicate moisture release. The cook uses tongs or a spatula to turn, separate pieces, and prevent sticking while browning progresses.
finished_description: End state: golden-brown, crackly crust on fried okra; slender, slightly curved pods about 2 to 4 inches long; surface blistered and evenly browned, sometimes speckled from batter; interior tender and warm with a creamy center; most moisture cooked out, minimal slime. The cook drains on paper towels and plates, possibly finishing with a sprinkle of salt or seasoning or serving with a dip.

initial_description: Initial state: raw pork pieces (strips or cubes) pale pink with white fat marbling, dry to slightly moist surface, uniform size, arranged in a single layer in a shallow pan with a small amount of oil. The pan may be warm and the oil shimmering. The cook is heating the pan and oil and placing the pork into the pan, patting dry if needed.
transition_description: During frying, pork pieces sizzle and release moisture; surface browns in patches while the centers stay pale and opaque. Fat renders, glossy pools form in the pan and droplets bead on meat. The crust crackles and thickens, edges curl and shrink slightly. Surface texture becomes mottled with sear marks; the cook turns pieces for even contact, guiding them with a spatula as steaming air rises.
finished_description: End state: Pork pieces have a crisp, golden-brown exterior, and a firm, opaque interior. The crust is well-browned and may blister; surface shows rendered fat sheen. Some shrinkage leaves pieces shorter and thicker than raw. Juices are mostly reabsorbed; the meat yields slightly to touch but remains firm. When done, the cook rests or plates the pork and may slice it for serving with sides.

initial_description: Initial state: Bananas peeled and cut into medium coins or elongated wedges. They are small-to-medium in size, with yellow skin and pale, firm flesh. Surfaces are smooth and unbrowned. In a preheated skillet, a thin layer of oil is present and the pieces are laid in a single layer, just beginning to touch the surface.
transition_description: As frying progresses, banana slices curl slightly and blister; edges brown to amber while centers become creamy and tender. The surface glistens with oil; bubbles surround the pieces as moisture evaporates. Slices may puff a little and soften in thickness. The cook uses tongs or a spatula to rotate, separate, and flip for even browning, adjusting heat and timing to avoid scorching.
finished_description: End state: banana pieces show a golden to deep amber crust, crisp outer layer with a soft, creamy interior; slight shrinkage and flattening from frying; glossy caramelized surface or sugary glaze. They are served warm, often with syrup or dusted sugar. The person finished might plate and garnish powdered sugar, cinnamon, chocolate or syrup, and taste or serve with ice cream.

initial_description: Initial state: bite-sized cauliflower florets, pale ivory with light green crowns, dry surface, stems trimmed, about 1–2 cm across. They are arranged in a single layer on a plate, not yet in oil. The pan or pot shows a small pool of oil warming; a subtle shimmer or tiny bubbles hint at heat. The novice may be rinsing, patting dry, and breaking larger florets into uniform pieces, preparing to introduce them to the hot oil.
transition_description: Florets in hot oil sizzle; surfaces blister, curl, and separate as moisture evaporates; color shifts from chalky white to pale gold with darker caramelized edges; exterior gains a crisp, slightly blistered crust while interior is tender yet still firm; oil foam subsides around pieces; pieces may cluster and shrink slightly; cook turns are frequent: flip/toss with tongs, adjust heat for even browning; pan may release wisps of steam.
finished_description: End state: cauliflower florets are golden-brown to amber, with blistered, crisp exteriors and tender, white interiors. Surfaces show light oil sheen; edges may be slightly charred. Pieces retain overall florets’ shape but are compact and a bit shrunken from moisture loss; some variation in size among pieces. After frying, the cook is plating or transferring to a serving dish, draining excess oil on paper, and finishing with salt, pepper, herbs, or dipping sauce.

initial_description: Initial state: raw carrot pieces, bright orange, uniform sticks about 4–6 cm long and 4–5 mm thick, straight and firm to the touch; surfaces are dry with a hint of moisture from washing. In the pan, oil begins to shimmer as heat rises. The cook is prepping: washing and peeling, trimming ends, patting dry, heating oil, and laying carrot sticks in a single layer to start frying.
transition_description: Mid-fry carrot pieces shimmer in hot oil with a steady sizzle. Color shifts from bright orange toward deeper amber as surfaces soften; edges may curl and skins loosen. Centers remain mostly firm but feel tender to the bite as moisture evaporates. The size slightly contracts as water leaves. The cook keeps turning and spreading slices for even contact, adjusting heat to sustain sizzle, prevent sticking, and encourage uniform moisture loss.
finished_description: End state: carrot pieces are golden-brown to deep caramel, with crisp, curling edges and a glossy oil sheen. They remain roughly the same shape but have shrunk and softened inside to a tender bite. Color is even, with possible caramelization. The fry is done when browning is even. The person finished frying carrot might drain on paper towels, season, and plate or toss with herbs and serve.

initial_description: Initial state: raw steak laid flat in a preheated skillet. Shape is oval or rectangular, thickness about 1–2 inches (2.5–5 cm); color a red-pink center with white marbling and pale fat edges. Surface may be damp or dry, not browned. The pan shows a thin oil sheen. A faint hiss or steam begins as it contacts the hot surface. The cook is readying to lower it with tongs, perhaps patting dry and seasoning beforehand.
transition_description: During frying, the steak shows a developing crust along the outer surface, browning from pale tan to deep amber; juices bead and steam escapes as fat renders. The center remains pinkish and denser, becoming firmer to the touch; edges may curl. Sizzle continues; surface glistens with a thin sheen. The cook flips, nudges, or tilts the pan, and may baste with butter while adjusting heat for an even sear.
finished_description: End state: a pan-fried steak with a golden-brown crust and crisp sear along the edges; size slightly reduced from cooking shrinkage; shape remains steak-like, roughly the original outline. Exterior is dry-to-juicy with a surface glaze; interior ranges from warm pink in medium to brown-through for well-done. Texture is firm yet juicy, with a slight chew. The cook rests it, then slices against the grain and plates it, possibly with sauce or butter.

initial_description: Initial state: raw meat pieces laid flat in a hot pan with a thin layer of oil. They maintain roughly the same shape and size as cut; surfaces pale pink to gray, moist with a slight sheen and a firm, raw texture. A faint sizzle may begin as surface moisture meets the hot surface. The cook is starting the process—preheating, adding oil, and placing the meat in with tongs.
transition_description: Meat sits in hot oil with the surface sizzling and small bubbles around edges. Color shifts from pink to opaque tan or brown as proteins denature and a light crust forms. Fat renders; juices bead and steam rises; edges curl and the piece shrinks slightly as moisture evaporates; surface tightens. The cook flips pieces with tongs for even sear, adjusts heat, and spaces pieces to prevent crowding.
finished_description: End state: meat presents with a golden-brown to dark-brown crust, crisp exterior from Maillard reaction, and a reduced, moist interior aligned to chosen doneness. The piece is typically smaller than raw due to moisture loss; shape remains roughly intact but may flare at edges. Juices are largely reabsorbed or lightly visible at the cut. The surface glistens with rendered fat. The cook is plating, resting, or slicing/serving the finished piece.

initial_description: Initial state: raw pepper pieces—uniform strips or chunks about 1–2 cm; colors green, red, yellow, or orange; skin smooth and glossy; flesh firm and crisp; seeds mostly removed. In the pan, a thin layer of oil shimmers but does not smoke, and the peppers are arranged in a single layer, showing no color change yet. The preparer is likely washing, deseeding, and cutting peppers, then heating a pan and adding oil before laying pieces in.
transition_description: Pieces of pepper sizzle in hot oil, blistering and curling at the edges, some skins splitting and wrinkling. The color shifts from bright green toward olive/yellow, with uneven browning in spots as surface moisture evaporates. The flesh softens yet remains with residual crispness in ridges; oil beads on glossy surfaces. Steam rises, bubbles skim the pan. The cook uses tongs to flip, separate pieces, and move them for even exposure and to avoid crowding.
finished_description: End state: Peppers are tender and pliable, with blistered or wrinkled skin and edges curling slightly. Flesh softened and glossy from oil; color ranges from vibrant green to olive or bronzed brown, often with dark speckling from caramelization or charring. Size appears reduced as steam escapes. The cook may be plating or tossing them into a dish, finishing with salt, herbs, or sauce.

initial_description: Initial state: unpeeled banana—curved, about 15–20 cm long, with smooth yellow skin and a green tint near the stem when underripe, or brown speckles if ripe. The skin is intact and slightly waxy; the stem sits at the top. The person grips the stem with one hand and begins to start peeling, typically preparing to pull the skin away from the top as the first motion.
transition_description: Partially peeled banana in progress: the yellow peel is pulled back in irregular ribbons along a curved fruit, leaving a central portion exposed. Remaining skin clings and flaps around the midsection, while the exposed fruit is pale cream, smooth, and slightly moist with a glossy surface. The fingers or thumb grip the stem area, maintaining the peel away from the fruit. The fruit length and diameter remain typical; some brown speckles may appear on the peel.
finished_description: End state: A ripe banana fully peeled, the yellow rind folded back along the sides to reveal a smooth, curved ivory fruit. The skin may show brown speckles; the flesh is soft and creamy. Ready to eat. The person finished peeling might lift it to bite, eat it, or place it on a plate or bowl.

initial_description: An unpeeled potato sits on a cutting board, whole and roughly fist-sized, oval to round in shape. Its brown-tan skin is dry, slightly rough, with a few eyes and minor dirt specks, and the flesh beneath is firm. A hand stabilizes the potato while the other holds a vegetable peeler at the skin, ready to begin peeling.
transition_description: On a cutting board, a potato shows a mix of skin and flesh as peeling progresses. Brown, textured skin remains in patches while pale, smooth flesh becomes visible. Edges are jagged where skin has been lifted; thin skin strips curl away. The potato shape stays roughly oblong, with the surface alternately matte skin and glossy moist flesh. A hand holds a peeler (or knife) at an angle, applying steady, circular or linear motions to expose more surface area.
finished_description: End state: peeled potatoes show a smooth, intact tuber shape—oval to oblong with uniform size. Skin is absent; outer surface is light pale cream to white, clean and slightly glossy. Flesh is moist, firm, and velvety to the touch, with eyes removed. The person finished peeling may rinse the potatoes, transfer them to a bowl or tray, or begin dicing and chopping for cooking.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole apple with unbroken skin, smooth surface, roughly 6–8 cm across, round to slightly flattened, color ranging red/green/yellow. Stem present. Flesh firm. At the start of peeling, the person grips the apple in one hand and positions a peeler or knife against the skin with light pressure, beginning to lift the edge.
transition_description: Mid-peel, the apple shows a contrast between remaining skin and exposed flesh. The peeled surface is smooth, pale, and glossy; edges remain crisp where the blade last met the fruit. Thin strips or patches of skin curl away, leaving curved, irregular boundaries around a spherical shape. The skin still covers portions of the fruit, creating alternating glossy skin and matte pale areas. The person uses a peeler/knife with a steady grip, rotating the apple and making even strokes.
finished_description: End state: A fully peeled apple, skin removed; the outer surface is smooth, pale cream flesh with a subtle glossy sheen. The apple retains its rounded, oblate shape, about the size of a fist, with the intact core in the center and seeds unseen. The texture appears firm yet moist; no bruising or discoloration where skin was. The person who finished peeling may slice it into pieces, place it in a bowl, or take a bite.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole onion on a cutting board, bulbous and round to oval, roughly 4–6 cm across. Its surface is coated with dry, papery skin—tan or pale brown, sometimes white—hiding smooth, pale flesh beneath; crisp when touched. The person is just starting: one hand steadies the onion, while the other begins to lift or pinch back a thin strip of the outer skin to expose the first layer.
transition_description: During peeling, the onion appears as a partially exposed bulb: a rounded shape with some papery outer skins removed, revealing pale white-to-yellow flesh and translucent inner layers. The surface is a mix of dry, flaky skins and moist, crisp rings. Remaining skin may curl at edges; color near peeled areas lightens toward ivory. The person grips the onion, uses a knife or peeler to lift off skin, and pulls or slices away successive layers, exposing underlying rings.
finished_description: End state: a fully peeled onion bulb with all papery skin removed. Surface clean, smooth, and firm; may be slightly moist. Color reflects variety (white, yellow, or red/purple inside). Shape is bulbous, typically round to slightly flattened; size remains typical for the bulb. After peeling, the person often rinses if needed and proceeds to chop or slice on a cutting board for cooking.

initial_description: Initial state: a garlic bulb with multiple cloves, each clove wrapped in a thin, dry papery skin. Colors range from pale ivory to light tan; cloves are small, almond-shaped or teardrop-shaped, about 1–2 cm long; surfaces are smooth and firm; outer skin is brittle, easily flaky. The person beginning peeling typically grasps a clove or the bulb and starts to lift or remove the outer papery layer with fingers or a knife.
transition_description: Intermediate state shows several cloves freed from the bulb but still partly wrapped in papery skin. Exposed flesh is pale, cream-colored, smooth and slightly glossy; remaining skin is thin, dry, wispy, sometimes translucent or brown-tinged. Some cloves have large patches peeled away, others retain multiple layers. The cloves may be separated or grouped, with skin fragments and moisture on the surface. The person uses fingers or a knife to pinch, peel, pry, or roll to loosen skins.
finished_description: End state: peeled garlic cloves—plump, teardrop-shaped, about 1 to 2 cm long, ivory-white to pale yellow, with smooth, slightly glossy surfaces and no papery skin. The cloves feel firm yet yielding and dry to the touch. They are often gathered in a bowl or on a cutting board, ready for use. The person may proceed to mince, slice, crush, or chop and add them to a pan or dish.

initial_description: Initial state: an unpeeled plantain, oblong and tapered at both ends, about 20–30 cm long and 3–5 cm thick. The thick skin is taut and waxy, usually green, with visible longitudinal ridges. The fruit feels firm and starchy inside. The person is gripping the stem end and starting to lift or nick the skin with a thumbnail or knife to begin peeling.
transition_description: The plantain remains oblong, palm-sized, with green-to-yellow skin in sections. A substantial portion of the thick peel remains, curling away in broad, fibrous strips; the exposed flesh is pale ivory to light yellow, firm and starchy, slightly glossy. The remaining skin is rough and leathery where not yet peeled. The person uses fingers or a knife to lift and strip the peel in long passes, rotating the fruit as needed.
finished_description: End state: A fully peeled plantain — elongated, slightly curved fruit about the length of a hand-span, with a thick, starchy flesh. The exposed interior is pale yellow to ivory, firm and dense, with a smooth, slightly moist surface. No skin remains. The person finished peeling may be about to slice, dice, fry, boil, or mash the plantain, or place the peeled fruit on a board to prep.

initial_description: Initial state: A smooth, oval egg about the size of a large chicken egg, with a white or light-brown shell and a firm, brittle feel. The shell is intact and unpeeled. The person is at the very start: cradling the egg in one hand, and the other to gently crack or lift a small patch of shell near the wider end to begin peeling.
transition_description: Partially peeled, the egg shows an oval shape with a mix of shell fragments and exposed surface. Regions still covered by shell retain white or tan coloration, while the central area is smooth, glossy, and pale, with the underlying egg white visible where the shell has peeled away. A thin, translucent membrane may cling to the edge, creating a ridged, damp boundary. The person holds the egg with fingertips, peeling in short, twisting motions, occasionally rinsing or patting dry.
finished_description: End state: a fully peeled hard-boiled egg, shell removed, intact oval about the size of a large egg. Exterior is smooth, glossy white; interior is opaque white with a pale yellow yolk visible when cut. Texture firm but tender; surface may be slightly moist. The peeled egg is typically being prepared for consumption or further processing—slicing, dicing, mashing, or plating—with hands nearby and a utensil or container ready.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole orange, round to slightly oval, about 6–9 cm in diameter, firm yet yielding to pressure. Thick, bright orange rind with a fine dimpled texture and a glossy surface; stem scar on top and a sunken blossom end. No peel removed. The person is just beginning to peel: one hand stabilizes the fruit, the other hovers at the rind, possibly applying a light pinch or small starter notch to loosen the surface.
transition_description: Partial peeling state: the orange is still round and hand-sized; rind torn into curling strips and ragged patches, partially detached. White pith (albedo) is exposed where the skin lifts, while the exposed fruit is bright orange, glossy, and slightly moist. Membranes may show as pale lines. The person grips the fruit with fingers or thumbnail, pulling and rotating to loosen rind, guiding peeling along the curve.
finished_description: End state: a fully peeled orange—no rind or most white pith; the fruit is a smooth, round to slightly oblate sphere about the size of a small orange; the bright orange pulp is exposed, with plump juice vesicles and thin translucent membranes visible. Surface is moist and glossy, with only minor pith remnants at segment junctions. The person finished peeling is eating it or separating segments onto a plate.

initial_description: Initial state: a fresh ginger rhizome—irregular, knobby, and tapered with several rounded lobes, roughly 5–8 cm long and 2–4 cm thick. The outer skin is thin, dry, and papery, tan-brown with fine wrinkles; the surface feels rough. Beneath lies pale yellow flesh, firm but fibrous. A person beginning to peel would grip the ginger with one hand and, using a peeler or paring knife in the other, apply light pressure to lift a skin strip from a protruding edge.
transition_description: In mid-peel, ginger displays a patchy surface: brown, papery skin clinging to knobby, irregular lobes of varying size, and exposed yellow flesh where skin has been removed. The interior is firm, fibrous, and glossy with visible radial fibers and moisture. Strips of skin peel away in ribbons from creases; some areas remain skinned while others show bare flesh. The person uses a peeler or paring knife, guiding it along ridges, rotating the piece to expose planes and smooth edges.
finished_description: Peeled ginger presents as irregular pale creamy-yellow chunks with the brown skin fully removed. The surface is smooth to slightly fibrous, moist but not slimy; edges are clean and the interior flesh is firm. Sizes vary from small shavings to thumb-sized pieces. The person finished peeling is likely slicing, mincing, grating, or placing the peeled pieces on a board or into a bowl for cooking.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole carrot, unpeeled, orange and cylindrical with a slight taper, 10–15 cm long. Skin is rough brown-orange with dirt specks; texture firm and crisp; ends intact. The person is just starting: one hand steadies the carrot on a surface, the other holds a vegetable peeler or knife, blade aligned at the rind and ready to begin contact.
transition_description: During peeling, the carrot surface shows alternating patches of smooth, bright orange flesh and thin, translucent or papery skin. Strips of peel curl away or lie in curled ribbons, sometimes damp from water. The exposed flesh is glossy and firm, slightly lighter in color where skin has been removed. The remaining skin may be rough with faint ridges along the cylinder. The person holds the carrot, guiding a peeler in circular or longitudinal motion, turning the vegetable as needed.
finished_description: End state: A fully peeled carrot with a smooth, bright orange surface, uniform cylindrical shape tapering to a point, consistent diameter along the length, no skin, slight moisture sheen, and firm, crisp texture. After peeling, the person is likely cutting or slicing the peeled carrot on a board, or washing and preparing it for cooking.

initial_description: Initial state: a fresh cucumber, intact and firm, cylindrical, about 6–8 inches long and 1–2 inches in diameter. Smooth, glossy green skin with lighter longitudinal stripes and a slight waxy bloom. The person holds the cucumber steady with one hand, and a peeler or knife in the other is positioned at the stem end, about to contact the skin as they begin the peeling motion.
transition_description: Partially peeled cucumber shows alternating zones: patches of glossy green skin remain, while adjacent stripes reveal pale, crisp flesh. The rind edges may be jagged or smooth depending on blade; the surface is moist and cool to the touch. The cucumber remains roughly cylindrical, with the diameter unchanged, length partly exposed. In progress, the person uses a peeler in long, even strokes, sometimes rotating the cucumber to cover all sides; small peel curls detach.
finished_description: End state: cucumber with skin removed; smooth pale green to almost white flesh; uniform cylindrical shape with rounded ends; firm, crisp, slightly glossy surface; no blemishes; consistent diameter. After peeling, the person may slice into rounds, dice, or transfer to a bowl or plate for a salad or garnish.

initial_description: Initial state: A whole lemon, unpeeled, roughly spherical to oblong, about the size of a clenched fist (2–3 inches diameter). Bright yellow, smooth yet slightly dimpled rind, glossy and firm; a small stem scar or navel may be visible. The person is just starting: gripping the fruit and placing a knife or vegetable peeler at the rind’s edge, poised to make the first shallow cut or lift a corner with a fingernail.
transition_description: Intermediate state: lemon still oval, rind partially removed in irregular patches. Yellow skin remains in places, white pith exposed in others; glossy juice beads on the surface; some curled zest ribbons detachably hanging. The exposed flesh is pale and slightly translucent where the rind is gone. The person is rotating the fruit and using a peeler/knife, applying pressure along the curve, pulling rind away in strips while leaving pockets of rind and pith intact as peeling continues.
finished_description:
End state: a fully peeled lemon—no rind or white pith—shaped roughly round to oval, about 5–6 cm in diameter. Skinless surface is smooth and slightly glossy; exposed pulp is bright yellow, moist, with visible translucent segments and membranes. No rind remains.

The person finished peeling may juice it, slice into wedges or rounds, or add the peeled fruit to a dish or bowl.

initial_description: Initial state: A whole, unpeeled tomato, about 2–3 inches in diameter, spherical to slightly flattened, with taut, glossy red skin and a small green stem scar at the top. The fruit feels firm with slight give. The person begins by gripping the tomato on a cutting board with one hand and lightly scoring or nicking the skin near the stem with a paring knife or thumbnail to loosen the skin.
transition_description: Partial peel in progress: the tomato remains roughly round and largely the same size, but skin peels away in strips or patches. The remaining skin is taut, sometimes torn at the edges; exposed flesh is glossy, red, and slightly translucent with visible juice and seeds. The peeled areas reveal lighter, firm, juicy interior with a softer, fibrous surface near the exterior. The person grips and pulls the skin, sometimes using a knife to loosen thin sections.
finished_description: End state: A peeled tomato with no skin; shape remains roughly spherical/oval, about the same size as before peeling. Exterior is smooth, glossy, and moist, with uniform red/orange color; surface may show a clean, pale edge where the skin was removed. Texture is firm yet yielding to light pressure; flesh intact, not shredded. The person finished peeling is likely transferring the tomato to a cutting board or bowl and slicing, dicing, or adding to a dish.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole squash, heavy and firm, with a smooth to lightly ridged rind. Shape varies from squat and round to elongated oval; length about 4–8 inches. Outer color depends on variety—cream, green, orange, or striped—with a hard skin and dense flesh beneath. At peeling start, it sits on a cutting board, stabilized, often with the stem trimmed or a flat base created, then a shallow peel or first cut begins.
transition_description: Partially peeled squash shows alternating patches of skin and exposed flesh, often in curved ribbons or irregular chips, patches varying in size. The skin color (dark orange-brown or green) contrasts with pale to bright orange flesh beneath; surface is damp and slightly glossy, with fibrous, stringy texture where skin has been removed. Edges are jagged where the blade moves, or smooth where a peeler skims. The person steadies the vegetable, rotates around the circumference, and guides the blade.
finished_description: End state: a completely peeled squash with skin removed, retaining its overall shape and size. Exposed flesh shows the variety’s color (orange for butternut, yellow for acorn, pale orange for spaghetti). The surface is smooth or lightly fibrous, firm and moist-to-dry, depending on variety. After peeling, the person may slice, cube, roast, steam, or rinse the flesh and scoop seeds.

initial_description: An intact avocado, oval- to pear-shaped and fist-sized, held or resting on a surface. Its dark green to near-black, rough, pebbly skin bears a small stem nub. The fruit is unpeeled, with pale green flesh hidden beneath. The person is just starting to peel: one hand stabilizes the fruit, the other prepares to lift the skin at the stem end.
transition_description: Mid-peel, the avocado shows partially removed skin in irregular patches, revealing smooth, glossy green flesh beneath. The boundary between skin and flesh is uneven, with peeled strips curling away and small tabs of skin still clinging. Exposed flesh ranges from pale green to yellow-green and may appear slightly moist or reflective. The person holds the halved fruit and uses a knife or spoon to loosen and lift skin along the curve, rotating the fruit to continue peeling.
finished_description: End state: skinless avocado flesh—typically two smooth, curved halves (or a single whole oval)—exposed flesh. Color ranges from bright to olive green with pale yellow center; creamy, buttery texture; surface free of rind and bruising. Size matches the fruit, about the length of a palm. The person finished peeling might be slicing, dicing, scooping into a bowl, or mashing the flesh for recipes.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole unpeeled mango—oval to oblong, about 6–12 cm long and 4–7 cm wide; skin green with yellow or orange blush, smooth and waxy. The fruit feels firm. The person begins by gripping the fruit with one hand (often at the stem end) and starting a shallow cut to loosen the skin with a knife or lifting with a thumbnail to begin peeling.
transition_description: Partial peeling reveals a boundary where bright skin gives way to orange flesh. Strips or patches of skin cling to the surface, curling at the edges. The fruit remains oval with a smooth, waxy skin under the cut areas; the exposed flesh is glossy, moist, and slightly fibrous. The person grips the mango, uses a sharp knife or peeler to shave away skin, rotating the fruit and pulling skin in sections.
finished_description: End state: peeled mango flesh exposed—skin removed, smooth, glossy, golden-orange flesh. The fruit is oval to oblong, juicy and tender with a slight fibrous texture near the seed. No rind; surface may glisten with juice. The piece is ready for cutting into cubes or wedges, or for scooping/eating. The person finished peeling might be slicing into chunks, dicing for a salad, or plating the flesh.

initial_description: Initial state: A whole eggplant, unpeeled, elongated oval about fist-size, with glossy purple skin and a green calyx at the stem. The skin is smooth, tight, and firm; color is deep purple with subtle shading. When starting to peel, the person holds the eggplant by the stem and positions a peeler or knife at the skin, preparing to begin removal.
transition_description: Partially peeled eggplant shows alternating strips of smooth purple skin and pale flesh. The surface is glossy where skin remains, and the peeled areas are pale ivory, moist and slightly spongy, with faint seeds near the center. The elongated fruit may curve and tilt as the person slides a peeler or knife along its length, lifting skin in irregular ribbons and rotating for access.
finished_description: End state: A peeled eggplant is an elongated, oval fruit with all skin removed. It is pale ivory to cream in color, smooth and moist, with a firm, fine-grained texture and trimmed ends. Size varies but is typically medium. The person might be slicing the flesh into rounds or chunks, or transferring pieces to a bowl/pan and preparing to cook (rinsing, patting dry, seasoning).

initial_description: Initial state: a whole pumpkin, unpeeled, with bright orange skin and faint vertical ridges; stem attached at the top; size from small to large, typically round or squat. The rind is firm and thick, with a slightly waxy texture and a few specks of dirt. The person begins by placing the pumpkin on a stable surface, gripping it, and starting a small cut or scoring line with a knife near the stem.
transition_description: Intermediate state shows a partly peeled pumpkin: patches of orange flesh exposed, interspersed with remaining glossy skin. Strips of rind curl away, creating irregular edges along the curved surface; the texture shifts from taut, waxy skin to rough, fibrous rind and moist, stringy pulp near the core. Color contrast: bright orange flesh against darker ochre remnants and pale inner membranes. The person is guiding a peeler/knife across the curve, rotating the fruit and lifting loosened skin in smooth motions.
finished_description: End state: fully peeled pumpkin—skin removed, orange flesh exposed, smooth, uniform surface, firm and moist, with no rind or seeds visible. Shape remains rounded/oblong, size unchanged. The person who has finished peeling is likely slicing or dicing into chunks, or placing the prepared pieces into a bowl, pan, or roasting tray for cooking.

initial_description: Initial state: whole shrimp in its intact shell, curved with a tapered head and fan tail. Size ranges from small to large; color depends on state—translucent grayish raw shrimp or pink-orange cooked. The shell feels firm and slightly slick; legs and antennae are present. The beginner typically picks up one shrimp by the tail or head, stabilizes it with the other hand, and begins to lift and grip a corner of the shell to start peeling.
transition_description: Partially peeled shrimp show a curved body with patches of translucent gray meat exposed where the shell has been removed. The remaining shell forms crescent arcs along the sides and tail; the dorsal vein may still be visible. The meat is moist and glossy, with a firm, springy texture. The person holds the shrimp by the tail or head, peeling backward segment by segment to expose more flesh.
finished_description: End state: peeled, deveined shrimp with all shells removed (tails may remain). Bodies are smooth, curved, plump, and uniform in size. The flesh is translucent grayish-pink when raw and becomes opaque pinkish-white with a pearly sheen when cooked. Texture is firm and moist, not rubbery. After peeling, the person might rinse, pat dry, season, marinate, or begin cooking (sautéing, boiling, grilling).

initial_description: Initial state: a fresh pear sits upright on a cutting board; size medium, weight balanced. Skin taut and smooth, color greenish-yellow to russet, with a glossy, waxy surface; stem end visible. Flesh pale beneath. No peel removed yet; slight blemish near the stem. The hand of the preparer anchors the fruit with the non-dominant hand, while the dominant hand holds a peeler at a shallow angle, ready to begin a light stroke around the circumference.
transition_description: Mid-peel, the pear keeps its pear shape; large patches of peeled flesh contrast with remaining skin. Skin peels away in thin ribbons or flakes, curling along the contour. Exposed flesh is white to cream, moist and slightly translucent; peeled areas look smoother and lighter than the remaining skin. The person uses a peeler or paring knife, rotating the fruit and drawing the tool downward or along the curve, producing continuous strips with occasional juice beads.
finished_description: End state: A pear with all skin removed, exposing smooth, pale cream flesh that is firm and juicy. It retains its oval, tapered shape and medium size; the surface is slightly glossy and uniform in color, with no rind. The core remains inside. The person finishing peeling is likely about to slice, dice, or eat it, or place it for cooking or serving.

initial_description: Initial state: an unpeeled beet, roughly 2–3 inches long, with a round-oval shape; dark red-purple skin still dirty from soil, skin intact and firm to the touch. The person starts by gripping the beet in one hand and placing a vegetable peeler against the skin with the other, ready to lift or draw the blade to begin peeling near the top edge.
transition_description: Partially peeled beet: the tuber is still mostly rounded and tapered, with skin removed in uneven patches. Exposed flesh is bright magenta-purple; remaining skin is dark purple and papery. The surface may be moist and slightly glossy where skin has been removed, with thin peel fragments curling away. The worker uses a vegetable peeler or knife, rotating the beet and scraping skin in streaks, occasionally lifting a strip to reveal the flesh beneath.
finished_description: End state: peeled beet with a smooth, skin-free, glossy surface; round to slightly oblong, about 2–3 inches in diameter; flesh deep red to magenta (golden beets are yellow-orange); firm and dense, with minimal surface moisture. The person finished peeling is likely slicing or dicing for cooking (roasting, boiling, or adding to salads) or placing the peeled beet in a bowl or container for storage.

initial_description: Initial state: a fresh zucchini—elongated, 15–20 cm long, 3–4 cm in diameter, firm and crisp; smooth green skin with faint lighter stripes, glossy and waxy; stem end intact, tapered ends. On a cutting board, one hand stabilizes the vegetable while the other grips a peeler, blade aligned with the skin near the stem, poised to begin the first pass of peeling.
transition_description: During peeling, the zucchini stays roughly cylindrical, green skin remaining in places while other sections are peeled to pale green-white flesh. Exposed flesh is smooth, firm, slightly glossy and moist; peeled areas show a color contrast and faintly waxy texture. Skin strips curl away in ribbons; the blade's path leaves irregular, intermittent edges. The person holds a vegetable peeler, rotates the zucchini, and draws the blade lengthwise from end to end in steady strokes.
finished_description: End state: a peeled zucchini with skin fully removed, exposing pale green–white flesh that is firm and moist. The surface is smooth, glossy, and evenly cylindrical, with clean, hydrated ends; no skin fragments remain. Size matches the original fruit (variable). After peeling, the person may rinse and pat dry, then slice or dice on a cutting board, or transfer to a bowl for cooking.

initial_description: Initial state: a raw prawn in its intact shell, head attached, body curved in a C-shape. Size varies from 4–12 cm depending on species. The shell is translucent gray-blue, smooth and firm; segments show pale rings, with antennae and legs protruding. Flesh beneath is moist and pale. The person starting to peel grips the prawn near the head and begins to lift the shell away from the body with thumb and forefinger.
transition_description: Mid-peel prawns show partial shell removal: the curved body is partly exposed, with translucent flesh visible where the shell has lifted away. The remaining shell clings along the back and tail, edges jagged from being peeled. The surface is moist and glossy; segments of carapace may still adhere near the head. The person grasps the prawn, pinching near the seam and pulling the shell toward the tail to reveal more meat, unchanged, and sometimes deveining as they go.
finished_description: End state: peeled prawns with shells and most veins removed. Bodies are elongated, curved, and uniform in size; flesh is smooth, moist, and translucent gray-pink. Surfaces are glossy with clean, tactile firmness. Tails may be left on or removed depending on prep. After peeling, the person is rinsing, patting dry, and placing them in a bowl or onto a tray, ready for cooking or marination.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole, unpeeled pepper with intact stem, smooth, glossy skin, and firm texture. Shape ranges from blocky bell to slender hot varieties; size roughly 2–4 inches tall. Color varies by cultivar (green, red, yellow, orange). Exterior is crisp to the touch; interior remains closed and unseen. The beginner is gripping the pepper, stabilizing it on a cutting board, and may be beginning to lift or cut a patch of skin to start peeling.
transition_description: Intermediate peeling state: the pepper is in the process of peeling, with skin in ragged strips clinging and curling away from glossy, moist flesh. Inner surface is exposed where skin has yielded, revealing pale green or white tissue and glistening membranes. Seeds and white ribs remain in the core. The remaining skin edge is uneven, with a few thin, translucent curls. The pith is intact but softened; fingers or a peeler grasp, pull, rotate, and trim.
finished_description: End state: skin fully removed from the pepper; smooth, glossy flesh; shape intact (whole or neatly halved/quartered); color remains vivid (red, yellow, orange, green); interior membranes and seeds removed; cavity clean and moist or dry depending on handling; flesh crisp-tender when raw, or soft if cooked. The person finished peeling might be slicing into strips, dicing, or halving to prep for cooking or roasting.

initial_description: The shallot is whole, small to medium, teardrop-shaped, with a tight, dry papery skin. The bulb is firm and smooth beneath, color ranging from pale yellow to purple depending on variety. The outer layer is thin and flaky but intact. When starting to peel, the person grips the shallot on a cutting board and begins to loosen or lift the papery skin with fingernails or a small knife, perhaps trimming the root end to begin removal.
transition_description: During peeling in progress, the shallot shows partially removed papery skins clinging in flaky, brownish strips. Exposed flesh is pale purple-white, firm at the core with fine, translucent onion rings visible where layers separate. The surface feels crisp and slightly damp from cutting, while the remaining skin remains dry and papery around the tip and root. The person uses a knife or fingers to loosen and lift skins, revealing a clean seam along the roughly oval bulb.
finished_description: End state: peeled shallots are clean, skin-free bulbs with a smooth, slightly glossy surface. They range from small to medium (about 1 to 3 cm), pale white to light purple, with the root end trimmed. The cloves are intact and firm, ready for use. They should feel dry though slightly moist to the touch, and free of papery skin. The person finished peeling may start slicing, dicing, mincing, or add them to a bowl for cooking.

initial_description: Initial state: a single, whole peach, roughly globe-shaped to oval, about 2.5–3 inches across. Fuzzy skin with a warm yellow-orange base and a red blush, sometimes green near the stem. The fruit yields slightly when touched, with a small brown stem remnant at the top. Early action: a person lifts the peach onto a board, holds it with one hand, and starts at the skin edge with a peeler or knife to begin peeling.
transition_description: Partially peeled peach shows skin removed in ribbons and patches, exposing pale orange flesh that is glossy with juice beads. Remaining skin clings in thin strips near the rim; fuzz on unpeeled areas remains. The fruit stays oval and plump, slightly smaller as peel comes off. The person holds the peach and uses a peeler or paring knife, rotating the fruit to expose new areas and lift peel in thin curls.
finished_description: End state: A fully peeled peach with a skinless, smooth, glossy surface. Flesh is juicy, velvety to slightly fibrous, orange-yellow with a pink blush, about the size of a tennis ball. The fruit retains a rounded, slightly flattened profile and is ready for slicing or eating. The person may be slicing into wedges, dicing for a salad, or biting into the fruit.

initial_description: Initial state: A whole pineapple stands upright, oval and medium-to-large, with thick, rough rind. Skin is green-brown with yellow hints, arranged in diamond-pattern scales and visible eyes. The flesh inside is not exposed, and the crown of green leaves sits on top. The person is starting to peel by stabilizing the fruit on a board and positioning a knife at the crown to trim it and begin removing the rind.
transition_description: Mid-peel, the pineapple shows rind removal: irregular yellow flesh exposed where skin has been stripped, with remaining brown patterned rind outlining the fruit. The edges around peeled areas are pale and glossy, slightly moist, with residual fibrous texture near the skin. The core remains visible at the center, untouched or only partially exposed. The handler uses a sharp knife, slicing downward and around the curvature, lifting rind in segments or spirals, rotating the fruit as needed.
finished_description: End state: A peeled pineapple shows smooth, golden-yellow flesh with rind and eyes removed. The fruit is compact and cylindrical, about the size of a small loaf, with a firm but juicy texture and a pale central core (or hollow center if cored). It’s ready to be cut into rounds or chunks. The person who finished peeling may now be slicing, dicing, or arranging the pieces for serving.

initial_description: Initial state: an unpeeled kiwi, oval to oblong, about the size of a small egg, with rough brown fuzzy skin and a hint of green beneath the skin. The beginning action: held steady in one hand; a peeler or paring knife contacts a small edge near the stem, lifting a thin strip of skin as the first peel begins.
transition_description: The kiwi is partially peeled, brown fuzzy skin remaining in patches or strips along the curved surface. The boundary between skin and exposed flesh is irregular; exposed flesh is bright green, juicy and glistening, with tiny black seeds visible near the center. The remaining skin curls away in places, and the fruit maintains its full size. A hand grips the fruit while a knife or peeler arcs around it, rotating to reveal more flesh.
finished_description: End state: peeled kiwis show smooth, skinless flesh. The fruit is oval, about the size of a large egg. Flesh is bright green with a pale central core and tiny black seeds in a ring; gold varieties have yellow flesh inside. Surface is glossy, juicy, and slightly crisp; the skin is removed cleanly. The person may now be slicing into rounds, dicing, or scooping to eat.

initial_description: Initial state: Raw onion pieces—sliced into rings or dices, about the size of a thumbnail to a bit larger. Color: white to pale yellow; shape: curved rings or irregular chunks. Consistency: firm, crisp, with surface moisture. When browning onion is just starting: in a preheated pan with a light coat of oil; sizzle begins and edges of pieces turn translucent. The beginner might be chopping/slicing, heating the pan, and adding the onion into the pan.
transition_description: Mid-browning onions are plump but shrinking, often translucent to pale amber, with edges curling and some surfaces turning tan to light amber. They glisten with oil as moisture evaporates; the interior is tender, while outer layers show speckled caramelization. Small brown fond bits form at the bottom. The cook stirs occasionally, adjusts heat to maintain sizzle, and may deglaze or scrape the pan to blend sugars and prevent sticking.
finished_description: End state: onions are soft, shrunken, irregular pieces with a glossy, deep amber to mahogany brown surface. They are jam-like, velvety, and slightly sticky to the bite, with a sweet caramel aroma. The cook might be deglazing the pan, scraping fond, and emulsifying the onions into a sauce, or tipping them into the dish and adjusting seasoning.

initial_description: Initial browning stage: chicken pieces lie flat in a hot, lightly oiled pan; shape is intact (fillets or chunks) with even thickness. Exterior surfaces are still pale pink to translucent, with a slight sheen from moisture and oil. The first signs of color change appear as the outer layer begins to become opaque, and the edges just begin to set. The cook’s action: heating the pan, adding oil, and laying pieces in a single layer.
transition_description: As browning progresses, chicken pieces show shrinking and slight curling at the edges. The surface transitions from pale to golden-brown in spots, with a gloss from rendered fat and reduced moisture; centers remain pinkish to light tan in some areas while contact surfaces crust. Edges develop crisp micro-crusts; texture shifts from slick to unevenly textured, with tiny ridges. The cook uses tongs to turn pieces, adjust heat, and rotate pan for even sear and fond formation.
finished_description: End state: The chicken shows a uniform golden to deep brown crust across the surface, with crisp edges and caramelized, slightly blotchy appearance. The piece is compact with minor shrinkage; exterior is firm and dry to the touch, while the interior remains fully cooked. After browning, the cook may rest the meat, deglaze the pan, add sauce, or move it to the oven to finish.

initial_description: Initial state (just starting browning): garlic pieces—peeled cloves or thinly sliced/minced bits—are ivory-white, sometimes with papery skin, and glossy yet firm. Shapes range from whole 1–2 cm cloves to flat slices a few mm thick or tiny granules; size varies by cut. They sit in a shallow pool of oil in a preheated pan; barely any color, with a faint sizzle just beginning. The beginner is heating oil and adding garlic, stirring or spreading it to distribute heat.
transition_description: During browning, garlic shifts toward warm straw-yellow with edges turning golden and speckled brown. Slices curl slightly, becoming translucent as moisture evaporates; surfaces glisten with oil, and small, uneven browning marks appear along edges. Internals stay tender while exteriors crisp in spots as color deepens and pieces may shrink slightly. A gentle sizzle marks progress. The cook stirs, tilts, or shuffles the pan to distribute heat and prevent hotspots.
finished_description: End state: garlic is uniformly golden to amber brown with crisp, slightly curled edges; pieces have shrunk and are dry yet firm, with a light oil sheen. No raw white remains; burnt bits are avoided. The aroma is toasty and nutty. After browning, the cook typically removes the pan from heat or transfers the garlic to a plate, then proceeds to deglaze or fold it into a sauce or final dish.

initial_description: Initial browning state: the meat’s surface remains mostly raw and pink-red, bounded by a glossy, moist sheen. At the very edge in contact with the hot pan, you’ll see tiny, pale-to-light-brown specks just beginning to form. The texture is soft, with little resistance to a gentle touch. A faint sizzle is audible as fat begins to render. The cook has preheated the pan, added oil, and laid the meat in a single layer, patting dry if needed.
transition_description: During browning, the meat shows a patchy, developing crust with a matte-to-glossy surface. The outer area turns golden to deep brown while the center stays lighter; edges may curl as fat renders. The surface is slightly dry with a tacky, crisp crust, while juices bead or hiss in the pan. The meat contracts slightly, shrinking in size. The cook flips and nudges pieces for even contact and sustained sizzle.
finished_description: End state of browning meat: a uniform, sealed crust of deep golden to dark amber brown across the surface, with a dry, slightly crisp exterior. The piece’s shape and size are unchanged; surface texture is firm, not glossy. Interior color varies by doneness but remains moist in the center. After browning, the cook may rest the meat, deglaze the pan, or transfer to finishing in sauce or oven.

initial_description: Initial state: Beef pieces sit in a hot, dry skillet in a single layer, still mostly raw. The interior remains red-pink; the outer surface begins to gray-brown where contact with the pan first occurs. A light sheen of fat and moisture darkens the surface, and a faint sizzle may be audible. The person starting browning is likely placing the meat in the pan and spreading it to maximize pan contact, without stirring yet.
transition_description: During browning, beef appears as irregular chunks or crumbles with a speckled crust. Exterior surfaces turn tan to deep brown via Maillard reaction, while interiors may stay pinkish-gray. Fats render, glistening in the pan, and juices bead or steam rises. Pieces brown unevenly; edges crisp while centers stay tender. The cook stirs, turns, and separates clumps with a spatula to increase surface contact and even browning.
finished_description: End state: beef pieces are uniformly browned on all exposed surfaces; color ranges from light brown to dark mahogany; exterior is slightly crisp or crusty while interior is firm and juicy, with minimal surface moisture; fat is rendered; pan shows fond. Depending on cut, shapes are small to medium irregular chunks or crumbled bits, somewhat reduced in size from shrinkage. The cook is likely deglazing the pan and building a sauce or adding aromatics to finish.

initial_description: Initial state (just starting to brown): raw sausage links or pieces in a hot pan. Shape remains cylindrical or curved; size is uniform. Exterior is pale pink or grayish with a glossy, moist surface; small white fat flecks visible; casing, if present, smooth and intact. Texture is firm yet pliable; only a trace of color at the very edges as fat begins to render. The cook preheats the pan and places sausages with space, optionally adding a light oil.
transition_description: During the in-progress browning, sausage pieces sit in a hot pan, centers pliable as exteriors darken and shrink slightly. Surfaces show uneven browning, with pale gray-brown patches transitioning to honeyed brown. Edges curl and render small crisps as fat pools and sizzles. The texture shifts from plump, moist to slightly crisper, with surface moisture evaporating. A gentle, steady hiss accompanies bubbling as juices migrate outward. The cook flips and nudges pieces for even color.
finished_description: End state: sausage is fully browned with a rich tan to dark brown surface, crisp edges, and a caramelized crust. Exterior may be crisp; interior fully cooked (no pink), juicy, with rendered fat integrated. Size may shrink slightly from fat loss; shape is irregular if crumbled or formed into links or patties. The cook may drain fat, plate, rest, or add it to a pan sauce or dish.

initial_description: In the pan, butter sits as pale yellow, solid chunks or pats, about 1–2 cm thick. The surface is glossy, with no significant liquid yet; edges may be just starting to soften as the heat comes up. A tiny pool of melted fat may cling at the bottom, but most of the butter remains solid. The cook is likely turning on medium heat and placing the pieces into the skillet, possibly cutting or spacing them for even melting.
transition_description: Mid-browning butter shows a shimmering, translucent pool of melted fat with intermittent white foam on the surface. Milk solids swirl and separate, sinking to form specks that gradually take on amber-brown edges. Bubbles grow smaller, the liquid becomes richer and more viscous; the color shifts from pale yellow to gold and then to light amber. The aroma deepens as toasty notes appear. The cook tilts and swirls the pan, skims foam, and nudges the pan for even heat.
finished_description: End state: a smooth, glossy pool of browned butter—the color ranges from amber to deep brown—with a nutty aroma. The liquid fat is pourable and slightly viscous; toasted milk solids may be visible as tiny brown specks, either suspended or settled at the bottom of the pan. The surface forms a thin, shallow pool rather than a solid mass. The cook may be pouring it into a sauce, finishing a dish, or drizzling over components.

initial_description: Initial browning crust appears as tiny irregular brown patches on a pale cream surface; patches are scattered, about 1–3 mm across, with color from pale beige to light amber. The surface remains soft and slightly tacky, with irregular, patchy shapes and no crispness yet. The baker has just exposed the dough to heat (in the oven) or begun applying a glaze/heat to initiate browning.
transition_description: Intermediate browning crust shows a developing, uneven surface: golden to amber patches with darker rims; center lighter, can be off-white or tan. Surface may be pale matte before fully drying, then glossy where fats/moisture remains. Texturally, it transitions from soft to crisp, with fine cracks and occasional blisters; edges may curl. Crust expands slightly as moisture escapes. Steam or vapour escapes, leaving a dry, crackly feel. The cook keeps heat steady, rotates, and brushes or baste for even color.
finished_description: End state of browning crust: the surface is uniformly golden to deep brown, often amber to mahogany, with a crisp, dry, crackly exterior. Texture shows slight blistering and flaky layers where applicable, and a firm bite. Edges remain intact and slightly darker; overall color is even with minimal pale spots. A light sheen from natural fats may be present. The baker is cooling the baked item on a rack, then ready to slice or serve.

initial_description: Initial state: bacon slices laid flat in a skillet, still raw as heat is applied. Shapes are long, straight strips with uniform width; meat color pinkish-red, fat white and opaque. Surface is moist and slightly glossy, not yet dry. Slices are pliable, not curled or crisp. The person has just placed the strips in the pan and started heating, allowing the fat to begin rendering and the meat to warm.
transition_description: During browning, bacon shows patchy browns from golden to deep amber; fat renders, turning translucent and pooling as strips shrink and curl; edges lift and become crisper while centers remain supple, creating a contrast of textures. The surface becomes glossy with released oil; sizzle and tiny bubbles mark moisture loss. The cook uses tongs to flip, reposition, and separate strips to promote even browning and prevent sticking.
finished_description: End state: evenly browned to golden‑brown or deeper amber, with crisp, crackly texture. Edges curl and shrink slightly; surface shows rendered fat with a light sheen; meat is firm with a crisp snap, not rubbery. Slight color variation from lighter centers to darker rims. After browning, the cook drains on paper towels and plates the bacon, often serving with eggs or in a dish, while saving the fat for reuse.

initial_description: Initial browning state: pork pieces in a single layer, varying shapes and sizes (slices or cubes). Outer edges show the first faint browning; the centers remain pink with surface moisture and a light sheen. Fat rims stay pale. The meat feels firm but pliable. A faint sizzle from the hot pan signals contact with oil. The cook has just placed the pieces down, patting dry and avoiding crowding.
transition_description: Pieces show partial Maillard browning: surfaces mottled from pale-tan to golden-brown with darker edge points. Some areas are crisp, others remain slightly soft and moist. Fat renders at the margins, glistening. Shrinkage and slight curling occur as moisture evaporates. Pan sizzle persists; spatula or tongs are used to flip or rearrange pieces to maintain even contact and browning.
finished_description: End state: pork pieces have an even Maillard crust from light golden to dark brown, with crisp, well-defined edges; size and shape match the cut. Exterior is dry and slightly tacky; surface shows caramelized bits (fond). The interior continues to cook to doneness; after browning, the cook may rest, deglaze, slice/serve, or add to a dish.

initial_description: Initial browning state: meatballs are roughly spherical, about the size formed (no change in overall dimensions yet). Exterior begins to color to a light tan or gray-brown; interior remains pink. The surface may glisten with a thin layer of rendered fat and moisture. A gentle sizzling is audible as the bottom makes contact with a hot pan. A beginner might be preheating oil in a skillet, shaping a meatball, and carefully lowering it into the pan without crowding.
transition_description: Intermediate browning shows a roughly spherical meatball with a slightly flattened contact area from the pan. Size may shrink a bit as surface moisture evaporates. Exterior color progresses from pale pink to golden-brown with a darker edge and a developing crust; surface becomes dry and slightly crisp where in contact. Juices bead and render fat, while the interior remains tender. The cook is actively turning and repositioning for even sear, adjusting heat, and lifting to check color and pan fond.
finished_description: End state: A browned, spherical meatball with a compact, crisp crust. Diameter about 1–2 inches, still roughly uniform in shape. Exterior color ranges from golden to dark brown with Maillard crust and slight sear marks; surface is textured, crackled, and firm to the touch. Inside remains moist and tender. The cook is likely finishing in sauce, removing from pan, or resting before serving.

initial_description:
- Initial state: Raw mushrooms with caps and stems intact; cap diameter 1–3 cm; slices 0.5–1.5 cm thick; color white to light beige; surface smooth and dry with a slight moisture sheen; shape convex-to-flat; texture firm yet yielding; no browning visible.
- Starter actions: washing or wiping clean; trimming stems; slicing into uniform pieces; preheating a pan with oil or butter for browning.
transition_description: As browning progresses, mushrooms show color shifting from pale to tan and amber as surface moisture evaporates and sugars caramelize. Caps darken and shrink slightly; edges curl and may crisp. Juices reduce, leaving a satin to lightly glossy surface; texture firms from soft and spongy toward a chewy bite. The cook is likely stirring or tossing in a hot pan, promoting even sear, moisture release, and surface browning.
finished_description: End state: Mushrooms are golden to deep brown with caramelized edges and a slightly crusty surface. They’ve contracted in size and may appear curled or flattened; overall shape is irregular. They are firmer and less juicy, and feel chewy yet tender inside; a light oil sheen may remain. For the cook, this finish usually leads to plating, tasting, or deglazing the pan to incorporate them into a sauce.

initial_description: Initial state: firm tofu cut into uniform cubes (about 1–2 cm), pale ivory-white, surface visibly moist but not wet. As browning just begins, only the outermost edges show the first light tan specks; the interior remains pale and intact, and the surface looks glossy from a thin oil film. The cook is likely pressing/drying the tofu and heating a lightly oiled pan before placing the cubes in a single layer.
transition_description:
- Color and surface: During browning, tofu surfaces blister and brown unevenly.
- Edges and shape: Edges curl slightly; centers remain pale but firming.
- Crust and color progression: Outer crust becomes light golden to tan, with a dry, crisp rim and darker specks.
- Texture and moisture: The interior stays spongy yet less moist as tiny air pockets form; pieces shrink a touch.
- Cooking actions: The cook flips, sears one side, moves pieces, and adjusts heat/oil to promote browning and prevent sticking.
finished_description: End state: Firm tofu pieces have a crisp, golden-brown crust on all exposed surfaces, with a slight caramelized sheen and darker edges. The exterior is crisp; the interior remains pale, dense, and chewy. Pieces may be slightly shrunk from their original size. The cook is plating or tossing the browned tofu with sauce or vegetables, draining excess oil, and readying for serving.

initial_description: Initial state: raw/thawed turkey pieces laid in a hot pan in a single layer. Surfaces are pale pink-gray, moist with a light sheen. Tiny irregular spots begin to tan where contact has started; edges may show faint color, but overall texture remains uncooked. The cook has just added a bit of oil and placed the pieces in contact with the pan, likely pressing gently for full contact and not yet flipped.
transition_description: During in-progress browning, surfaces appear mottled tan to bronze; the skin tightens as moisture evaporates. A thin, savory crust forms where pan heat concentrates; edges curl and crisp. Fat renders, droplets hiss on the surface, and juices glisten. The meat firms yet remains moist beneath. The cook may flip pieces, move them to even heat, baste with pan juices, or adjust heat to maintain sizzle without scorching.
finished_description: End state: the turkey or cut shows uniform golden-brown to deep bronze skin, crisp and tight with rendered fat sheen and occasional caramelized spots. The surface is dry to the touch, not pale, and the overall form remains recognizable though slightly smaller due to shrinkage. Once browning is complete, the cook is likely resting or tenting the meat, transferring to the oven or carving.

initial_description: Initial state: the steak lies flat, a uniform, thick block with a moist, shiny surface; interior remains red-pink. Where the pan first contacts, a few tiny brownish specks appear and a pale glaze forms on the top surface as heat begins. A sizzle starts but the crust is not yet formed. Beginning action: pat dry, heat a heavy pan until hot, add oil, lay steak in gently and leave it to sear without moving.
transition_description: During browning, the steak’s surface shifts from red/purple to pink-brown and then to deep brown as Maillard crust forms. A dry, crisp crust appears where it contacts the pan; fat renders and pools along the edges. Juices surface as steam bubbles rise; the steak may flex or flatten under heat. The cook maintains heat, watches color, nudges with tongs, and rotates or presses lightly for even sear and crust development.
finished_description: End state: The steak has a crisp, deeply browned crust with a uniform tan-to-mahogany color, a firm outer surface, and distinct sear marks. The interior has reached the target doneness, with juices largely contained. The steak’s shape remains roughly the cut’s original outline; size slightly reduced by moisture loss. The cook may be resting it, slicing against the grain, or deglazing the pan and plating.

initial_description: Initial state (before browning): raw potato pieces—uniform shape (slices or cubes), about 1 cm, firm, pale white to pale yellow, smooth waxy surface, slightly moist. Just starting to brown: faint tan specks at edges where heat first acts, surface still mostly pale. A beginner might be cutting/dicing, patting dry, and preheating a skillet with a splash of oil, ready to add the pieces.
transition_description: During browning, potato pieces exhibit a gradient from pale to golden as surface moisture evaporates. Edges develop a thin, slightly blistered crust while centers stay partly translucent and soft. The pieces may curl or shrink marginally; surfaces look glossy and then begin to matte as crispness forms. A sizzle and bubble activity persists around oil-exposed faces. The cook is flipping, shuffling, and adjusting heat, sometimes sprinkling salt or adding oil to maintain contact.
finished_description: End state: uniformly browned potato pieces with a crisp, crackly exterior and a tender interior. Color ranges from golden to deep amber/brown; surface shows a light oil sheen and little moisture. Shapes remain as cut (wedges or chunks); size unchanged, but edges are crisp and slightly curled. The cook may be plating, draining on paper towels, seasoning, or serving.

initial_description: Initial state: a single bread slice, rectangular with straight edges and uniform thickness. Size roughly 10×7 cm; about 1 cm thick. Color: pale cream crumb with a slightly tan crust; surface soft and porous, some visible air pockets; light moisture gives a gentle gloss. No browning yet. When just starting, minute golden specks or a faint edge tint may appear as heat begins to act. The person is placing the slice on a toaster or pan to begin heating.
transition_description: Intermediate browning shows a roughly rectangular slice or loaf with mild expansion and slight warping. The crust firms and crackles, edges curling and forming a shallow, uneven surface. The surface exhibits mottled hues of light tan to amber, with a few blisters or crack lines. The crust dries and tightens, while the interior crumb warms and becomes firmer and less tacky. The person checks progress, adjusts the toaster/oven, or rotates slices to even browning.
finished_description: End state: a loaf (or slices) with a uniformly golden to deep brown crust, crisp to firm texture, and an even, smooth surface. The loaf's final size matches its baked dimensions, with crust showing slight cracking in spots and even browning around the sides; interior crumb fully set with uniform, small air pockets. The baker has just removed it from the oven and placed it on a cooling rack, then may slice or butter.

initial_description: Initial browning state: Even-sized vegetable pieces laid in a single layer in a hot pan with a thin oil film. Surfaces remain pale with a faint tan edge just forming; moisture glistens briefly before evaporating. A light sizzle indicates contact heat. The cook is placing the pieces in the pan, spacing them to avoid overlap, and watching the surface for the first hint of browning, possibly adjusting heat or adding more oil.
transition_description: Intermediate browning appears as mottled surfaces with golden-brown patches and lighter tan areas. Edges may curl and become crisper while centers stay softer, producing a mixed texture. The vegetable surfaces develop a dry, slightly matte look with a light oil sheen; moisture evaporates and tiny juices bead or sizzle. Pieces shrink a bit and sometimes blister. The pan sizzles; the cook stirs, flips, or shuffles pieces to keep contact even and regulate heat.
finished_description: End state: Vegetables exhibit Maillard browning from golden to deep brown, with blistered, crisp edges and tender, slightly shrunk centers. Surfaces range from dry to lightly glossy, often with a caramelized, sugary sheen. Shape remains identifiable (slices, chunks, or whole pieces). Texture crisp-tender to firm with a browned crust. After browning, the cook may plate and serve, finish with seasoning or sauce, or deglaze and toss for a final coat.

initial_description: Initial state: dry, free-flowing granulated sugar in a pan; white to pale ivory crystals, uniform granule size, granular texture, no clumps. The beginner might place a dry skillet on the stove, sprinkle sugar into a thin, even layer, and spread it evenly with a spoon.
transition_description: During browning in progress, the sugar has melted into a glossy, fluid syrup that continues to thicken as water evaporates. The color shifts from pale gold toward deeper hues, while the surface shimmers and bubbles; foamy pockets may form as water escapes. The mixture is viscous but still pourable, with a warm, toasty aroma. The cook swirls or tilts the pan to distribute heat, watching for even color and avoiding scorching.
finished_description: End state: a glossy, uniform amber to deep copper caramel—liquid and viscous when hot, coating surfaces (spoon, spatula) with a thin film. On cooling it can harden into brittle caramel sheets or become chewy candy, depending on concentration and cooling. For the person finished, they’re likely off heat, preparing caramel sauce or glaze (adding cream/butter) or pouring/spreading it onto desserts as it sets.

initial_description: Initial browning onset occurs on a cut apple. The fruit is round, about the size of a fist; the exposed flesh is pale white/cream and still firm. Tiny brown-tan freckles appear on the surface near the cut. The intact skin preserves its red/green/yellow hue. A light, moist surface indicates freshness. The person is slicing or peeling with a knife, creating the fresh cut surface that starts browning.
transition_description: Intermediate browning: exposed flesh shifts from pale white to dull tan, with irregular brown patches spreading from cut edges; color gradients can be yellowish near fresh surface and darker in splotches. The surface remains relatively firm and size unchanged, but may feel slightly softened where oxidation concentrates; texture becomes matte and moist in some areas. The cut faces remain rectangular yet visually uneven, as the person slices, fans out, or sprinkles juice (e.g., lemon) to slow the reaction.
finished_description: End state: cut apples show brown surfaces from oxidation—colors range from tan to dark brown, with the underlying flesh still pale. The pieces remain in their cut shape (slices, wedges, or chunks); size roughly unchanged. Surface may feel dry or slightly waxy; interior flesh can be crisp near the surface or soft if exposed longer. The person finished browning might be plating, tasting, adding to a dish, or discarding the pieces.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole medium banana, about 6 inches long, gently curved, with taut yellow peel and no major bruising. Size is standard; peel smooth and firm. Color mostly bright yellow with a few tiny brown freckles beginning to appear. Flesh hidden, but surface remains intact. The person might be peeling back the skin, or slicing the banana to expose it to air.
transition_description: Mid-browning banana in progress: slices remain mostly intact but show slight shrinkage; edges curling, some flattening from heat. Color shows amber-brown speckling and caramel patches with a glossy surface. The fruit is soft and creamy in the center, with slightly firmer, syrupy edges. Translucent, blistered patches appear as moisture concentrates. Sweet caramel banana aroma fills the pan. The cook is turning slices, nudging with a spatula, adjusting heat and spacing to promote even browning.
finished_description: End state: the banana is fully browned—skin dark brown to black and easy to peel; fruit is very soft, mushy, and brown-cream with dark speckles; skin may wrinkle or collapse. The person finished with browning banana is likely mashing it for banana bread or muffins, blending into a smoothie, or mixing into batter for pancakes or desserts.

initial_description: Initial state: a whole onion on a cutting board, its dry papery skin largely intact. Globe-shaped and fist-sized (roughly 5 to 7 cm diameter). Outer skin tan-brown; underneath are compact, pale white, tightly layered internal rings. The onion feels firm and dense; root end and pointed top intact. The preparer stands at the counter, knife in hand and the opposite hand steadying the onion, about to start slicing.
